TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman), rising on a matter of privilege, referred to advertisements that had been placed in the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday, 20 September, in which his electorate office telephone number had been listed without his permission, and which had caused numerous unwanted calls to his office yesterday. In order to accord precedence to a motion, as Speaker I must be satisfied that a matter has been raised at the earliest opportunity, and that a prima facie case has been made out. I am satisfied that, in the circumstances, I should regard the matter as having been raised in time.

INTERJECT.PARA: The House may regard as a contempt any act or omission which obstructs or impedes a member in the discharge of his or her duty, or which has a tendency, directly or indirectly, to produce such results. As I understand the honourable member's complaint, he believes the problem has a relationship with activities in which he has been engaged in connection with visiting naval vessels. The honourable member has found that the work of his electorate office has been disrupted; it is not a matter of the honourable member being harassed or obstructed on account of his participation in proceedings in Parliament. The honourable member also advised that the matter had been referred to the police. I am not aware of any exact precedents for this set of circumstances. Nevertheless, there is a flexibility in the accepted definition of contempt which permits the House to protect itself and its members from new or novel threats or obstructions.

It needs to be stated that Parliament should provide reasonable protection to the House, its committees and members from substantial interference with the performance of their functions. Having given this matter careful consideration, I am prepared to accord precedence to a motion in connection with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister will be aware that his Treasurer lives in Canberra but claims travel allowances as though he lives in Sydney and that within an 11-month period he obtained over $17,000 in tax free allowances. I ask the Prime Minister: Why did six days go by before he answered my request for him to disclose the secret changes to the rules which it is now said enable the Treasurer to manipulate the system? Why in his reply is there no date recording the secret Cabinet decision? Is it not true that, even though the Government has tried to fiddle the system to protect the Treasurer, the Treasurer is still breaching the travel allowance rules? How does the Prime Minister explain to Australians, who are being taxed to the eyeballs by this Treasurer, that they have to play by the rules but the Treasurer does not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the first part of the question, it is very difficult to take the Leader of the Opposition or the Opposition seriously in their conduct in this place. I replied to the Opposition Leader's request in due time. The correspondence from him was not the most important matter I had before me. It has been replied to. I should set out the facts in regard to the way in which this Government has significantly improved the situation in terms of imposing limitations upon Ministers as to the circumstances in which they claim travelling allowances. It has been the practice for a long time for members of both sides of this House to maintain residences in Canberra because of the requirement that they be in Canberra for substantial periods of the year. This has been particularly so for Ministers whose duties require them to be in Canberra for extended periods, not just during the parliamentary sitting period but throughout the year. The Treasurer is an example of that.

ANSWER.PARA: Maintaining a second residence in Canberra, whether on a rental or a purchase basis, usually involves considerable expense for the member or the Minister involved. It is quite legitimate and reasonable that, where the second residence is not the member's or the Minister's principal place of residence, travelling allowance should be claimed as an offset to that expense. That is done by members on both sides of the House and by Ministers of this and previous governments. It is very important in such circumstances, as it is in all circumstances where expenditure of public funds is involved, that a prudent approach be not only adopted but also observed. Thus, in the Government's consideration of the 1983 Remuneration Tribunal report, the Government, having noted that the Tribunal had not provided a definition of `principal place of residence', provided specific guidance for Ministers in this area. The substance of the Cabinet decision was that as guidance for Ministers, it would be appropriate for Ministers who also maintained residences in Canberra, when absent from the principal place of residence in their home State for extended periods on official business in Canberra, to claim the appropriate travelling allowance only for the weekdays involved. The Treasurer has scrupulously adhered to that Cabinet decision.

It should be appreciated that this Cabinet decision was a self-imposed limitation upon the decision of the Remuneration Tribunal. It would have been open to the Treasurer, had he so chosen, to claim days other than the weekdays. We imposed that limitation upon our Ministers and the Treasurer has scrupulously observed it. It is for the Leader of the Opposition, if he so wishes-he seems to have a very considerable interest in this matter-to disclose the practice in this matter of all members on his side of the House. We were able to impose a limitation upon our Ministers, and we did so. If the honourable gentleman opposite, who raises so piously and pompously these questions of propriety on the part of Ministers, would like to see the record of this Government compared with the record of his Government, he knows who would come out worst in that comparison. The previous Government's practice was absolutely appalling. The opportunity may well emerge for that practice to be disclosed. We were not prepared to condone the improprieties which characterised our predecessors' seven years in office. We specifically made a Cabinet decision which imposed, by our own voluntary decision, a limitation upon what would have been open under the decision of the independent Remuneration Tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Special Minister of State inform the House as to the administration and payment of travelling allowances under the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for McMillan for his question without notice. I was provoked into it only because the Prime Minister said that he would see that the information was made available as soon as possible. Firstly, I shall deal with the report in today's Press which said that Federal Cabinet is expected to consider shortly a submission from me on ministerial allowances. As the Parliament would know, I have responsibility for the preparation of only one submission a year on these matters, which submission goes to the Remuneration Tribunal. There is no review of the Tribunal's decisions because we have found there to be no breach of the decisions which it has made.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no need for me to go over all the points that have been made by the Prime Minister on the carrying out of the Tribunal's recommendations in these fields. I do not point the finger at anyone in either this Government or the previous Government because I think that by and large people have complied with what has been a very difficult ruling by the Tribunal. The Tribunal has had a very difficult task in trying to deal with the fact that hundreds of people, not only parliamentarians but also staff members, travel from all over Australia to service this national Parliament.

In the mid-1950s the Menzies Government started a system of giving low interest loans to Ministers for flats and houses, especially those Ministers who had responsibility for Canberra. If one goes through the list one finds that Hasluck, Freeth, Barwick, Gorton and McLeay-Ministers on both sides of the House-had access to low interest loans. Honourable members will recall that in the last period of the Fraser Government there was great controversy over the fact that the then Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, was living in a house that was given to him on a 4 per cent interest loan when he was a junior Minister in 1964. He was in that house whilst Murwillumbah was his principal place of residence.

That system is no longer available. It was started by the Menzies Government. It was used by the Holt, McMahon and Gorton governments and, to some extent, by the Whitlam Government, but it is not a system which is carried on. The granting of a 4 per cent loan to Ministers for houses in Canberra which they were paid travelling allowances to stay in is not a system which persists today for anybody, but it was available in those days. It was available up until a couple of years ago when I think the last person in any of those houses, Doug Anthony, resigned from this Parliament.

Let us look at the system that applied under the previous Government. Whilst the present Leader of the Opposition may not have had the problem because he lives close to Canberra, in Sydney-I think that people who live in Sydney and Melbourne have a distinct advantage over people who live elsewhere in Australia-he was the Treasurer and he did have some responsibility for the system. He cannot get up in this Parliament and say: `I shall be holier than thou, but my eyes were closed from 1975 to 1983'. As the then Treasurer of the country, if he thought there was something wrong with the system, he should have done something about it. In the last year of office of the Fraser Government, Doug Anthony, with his home base at Murwillumbah and a home that he owned in Canberra on a 4 per cent loan, claimed 180 days travelling allowance with 53 days overseas. The honourable member for Gwydir, whose home was in Moree, claimed 261 days travelling allowance. Peter Nixon, who also had a home here-he owned a place on another low-interest loan-claimed for 208 days with 60 days overseas. Our old mate, the right honourable member for New England, whose principal place of residence was Bendemeer, claimed 248 days travelling plus 32 days overseas. Tony Street had his home address at Barwon Heads.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is that?

—Barwon Heads is in the electorate of the honourable member for Corangamite. He had 187 days, with 69 days overseas. That was the last year. If we go back to 1981, we come to some more interesting figures. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment will give two free tickets to Crocodile Dundee to the person who can think of who claimed the most in 1981. In 1981, the right honourable member for New England had his principal place of residence at Tamworth, and he claimed 286 days. We nearly had to get Pope Gregory back to give us a new calendar to fit in his travelling allowances. He must have been crooked on home cooking. Mr Street, again at Barwon Heads, claimed 235 days travelling. The honourable member for Gwydir, again at Moree, claimed 245 days.
—Totally irrelevant.

—The Leader of the Opposition says that it is now irrelevant. It was irrelevant then, but it is relevant now. The interesting thing is that, in 1981, when the address of the right honourable member for New England was Tamworth, he spent 141 days in Canberra and 119 in Sydney. Incidentally, there has never been a submission from the coalition to the Remuneration Tribunal about changing the system-not one.
—We had a Cabinet decision.

—Oh yes? Tony Street, who had Barwon Heads as his principal place of residence, had 95 days in Canberra, but 134 days in Melbourne, which is not far from Barwon Heads. The honourable member for Gwydir had 216 days in Canberra. No one was pointing the finger at those people. That was the system that operated. Interestingly enough, the only thing that occurred was that, without any submission from any of the parliamentarians of the political parties, the Tribunal changed its interpretation in 1982. It used to say `home base' and then it changed it to `principal place of residence'. When I made some inquiries, the Tribunal said that it did it because of suggestions coming from the Department. The then Minister was the honourable member for Bass, Mr Newman. But it did not change anything. Someone queried it in the Senate and said that if it had been left as `home base', perhaps all the people I have mentioned would not have been entitled to claim the travelling allowances which they had claimed. But it was changed to `principal place of residence', which meant that Tamworth, Moree, Barwon Heads or whatever it may have been, could still be included as the principal places of residence.

ANSWER.PARA: All that I say to the new members who raised this and who might not know any better-perhaps on this occasion they stand excused-is that to other people who have had to live with this difficulty for a long time, the rort in the system was the low interest loan. That is no longer available. If the national Parliament requires some people to make a decision to have two homes instead of one because of their position in the national Parliament, that is something that has to be acknowledged. If people have better ideas about the way the systems ought to apply, they should go to the Remuneration Tribunal and tell it to change the system. But to point to the Treasurer under these circumstances, when internal discipline has been applied, as the Prime Minister said--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a joke.

—There has been a limit. There was no limit on the Leader of the Opposition-286 days of travel. All I am suggesting is that the Leader of the Opposition is now cognisant of something which he thinks is wrong, but for seven years, when he was in charge of the Treasury, he did not think it was wrong. There was a Cabinet decision no one knows about which might be of interest. I would like to know what impact that Cabinet decision had and how it changed the system. It will be very interesting to hear about that from the Leader of the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: This attack on the Treasurer comes about because of the complete failure and ineptitude of the Leader of the Opposition in leading a political party. Because the Leader of the Opposition is so weak, he has told his party room not to use Question Time. He is the first leader of a party operating under the Westminster system who has told his political party to forget about Question Time. He does not deserve to lead a political party. He wants to raise this matter because he cannot debate the major issues. He should ask the Treasurer about some of the major issues. He has told his party room that he will not do so because the Treasurer does him over all the time. That is what this attack is all about, and everybody in Australia should realise it.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. How can he, with any sense of honesty or decency, claim untaxed travel allowance--

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that we get these questions from the Opposition, because we have not been getting any questions about the broad thrust of public policy. The Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong, has been under a cloud for most of the period he has been Leader of the Opposition. He has emerged briefly from it only to take advantage of the problems of the economy brought upon Australia by external trading conditions. He says: `The times are for me'. In other words, he thinks he can prey on the bad times. He seeks to treat the Parliament with contempt and will not use its forums for the legitimate purposes of opposition. He says, when asked by members of the Press Gallery to explain his fiscal policy, that he will not. He gives them a dose of old Liberal Party arrogance, saying: `We are on the way back. We won't explain, and we don't need to explain'. In other words, it is a party with no policy, no framework, no structure, which does not defend itself in the Parliament, will not explain its policies, and preys on Australia's bad fortune in international markets.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the only manifestation of the current Liberal leadership that we have seen. But now the new John Howard gets up to concentrate on my travelling allowance. That is the burning national issue. A major structural change in the economy is taking place. We are rebalancing the whole of the economic fabric of this country. We are doing what he did not do. His plundering of the manufacturing sector robbed our fight-back capacity on the current account, in the face of these depressed trading conditions. He is not interested in that. He is intent only on talking the economy down and focusing on the economic difficulties. If he thinks that the serious people in this community, those in Australian business, who want to see this country prosper are impressed by this kind of behaviour, he is gravely mistaken. As the economy responds to the Government's strength of leadership and the optimism and decency of the millions of Australians who work and invest in the economy, he will be rolled up into the dustbin of history.

The concentration of the question is on my travelling allowances, and the central tenet of the question of the honourable member for Mackellar in his attack on me is that I am in some way removed from the Remuneration Tribunal's determination. Of course I am not removed from it. I am only here to do this job. If I were not, my family and I would be living as many days out of seven as possible in Sydney. If my wife and children were to return to Sydney tonight, there would be no issue here whatsoever. On the honourable member's judgment of the Remuneration Tribunal's determination, he is saying that I should do my job as Treasurer and work here six or seven days a week without my family, and expend my salary as Treasurer housing myself to enable me to do the job. Is that the honourable member's logic? Is he saying that I should use my salary of office as Treasurer to pay my rent to enable me to do the job? Of course that is nonsense.

However, the system was abused shamefully by the former Government when members of it changed their place of residence during the course of the year so that in the parliamentary recess they would have their home base at Canberra but claim the allowance when elsewhere, and when the House was not in recess their home base would be elsewhere but claims would be made for visits to Canberra. That is where the 245 days, the 235 days and the 286 days came from; that is how those claims were made.

In contrast, this Cabinet, at the start of its period of office, decided that there would be rules. As the Prime Minister said, this constrained Ministers who chose to carry out their jobs in Canberra by removing the capacity to claim the private component of the week, the weekend. Even though I work most weekends, or a great part of them, I claim nothing here. Let not the honourable member for Bennelong be righteous in this respect. I make the claim that the job of Treasurer cannot be done on the wire services or the facsimile machine, or by dragging stacks of staff to Canberra and, to suit himself, flying his staff to Sydney, housing them or accommodating them, as would be the case were I to choose to do that.

The fact is that the honourable member for Bennelong left this country with a massive and disastrous fiscal imbalance which we have spent three years pulling down. The Cabinet meets for five months a year to pull that back. It has done so now during the course of presenting four Budgets. Major changes have been made in the tax system, which the honourable member saw plundered, ripped and raped by the tax avoiders and speculators, and he has the temerity, with his disgraceful neglect of the tax system, to talk about travelling allowances in respect of my tax obligations or my capacity under the Remuneration Tribunal. Any claim that I have made has been totally in accord with the Remuneration Tribunal and the Cabinet decision. It has been determined appropriately and properly by the Cabinet at the start of its period of office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister give the House the Government's assessment of the moves in the international community to take economic measures against South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Fowler for his question. The 12 European Community foreign Ministers expressed their grave concern at their meeting on 15 and 16 September that South Africa had entered a new phase of increased tension under the state of emergency. They deplored the fact that the South African Government was not yet prepared to make possible a national dialogue across the lines of colour, politics and religion. In the light of this assessment, the 12 agreed that they should now adopt a package of restrictive measures. These consist of bans on new investment and on the import of iron and steel and gold coins from South Africa. Most of the 12 were also willing to implement a ban on the import of coal from South Africa, but because the agreement of all 12 is required that measure has not been endorsed. The United Kingdom presidency has undertaken to continue to seek consensus on this matter. Obviously, Australia would have preferred that the measures had gone further and had been more in line with the measures adopted at the London meeting of the Commonwealth, on which I reported to this House on 21 August. Nonetheless, we welcome these steps by the European Community. They provide a further move towards the international approach which we consider essential.

ANSWER.PARA: The Japanese Government issued a statement on the 19th of this month noting that the situation in South Africa showed no sign of improvement and was at such a serious stage that some steps had to be taken. As a result, the Japanese have announced the introduction of new measures, including a ban on the import of iron and steel from South Africa. As I think all honourable members of the House know, in the United States of America, the Senate anti-apartheid Bill has now been passed by 308 votes to 77. The main provisions of that Bill are a ban on the import of South African uranium, coal, textiles, steel and agricultural products, no United States landing rights for South African Airways, a ban on the South African Government operating United States bank accounts except for diplomatic purposes, and an indefinite extension of the limited sanctions imposed by President Reagan's executive order last year and renewed earlier this month-that is, bans on the import of Krugerrands, United States bank loans to South Africa and certain computer technology. The Government would hope that the President will sign the Bill into law.

The Australian Government regards the emerging consensus on South Africa in the international community as a vindication of the leading role that the Australian Government has played in the Commonwealth and elsewhere. It is interesting to note that in a statement issued yesterday in New York, under the heading `Imminent change needed for South African policy', the Chairman of the Opposition's foreign affairs committee, Senator Hill from South Australia, said:
The Opposition should support the growing consensus in the Western world that without economic pressure from outside, South Africa will continue with its policies of entrenched racism.

That is precisely the view of the Government, It is known to be shared, I must say, by other members of the Opposition as well as by Senator Hill. I might say that an obviously embarrassed honourable member for Kooyong this morning described the Opposition's policy on South Africa as `an evolving one'. That is just Libspeak for saying that he wants to dump it. The honourable member for Kooyong knows that it will not evolve under the present Leader of the Opposition until that Leader shows some real leadership and stops pandering to extremism on South Africa. The statement of the Leader of the Opposition to this House on 21 August was an extended argument against taking economic sanctions against South Africa of the kind now being increasingly introduced by the international community and now being espoused by the more enlightened members of the Opposition.

I say, finally, that one would hope that the Leader of the Opposition will have the courage and the decency to bring his Party into line with responsible Western policy on South Africa and into line with that of his predecessor Malcolm Fraser. But I am afraid that he will once again, as characteristic of his discharge of the position of leadership, take his lines on this, as from so many other things, from the more reactionary people in his coalition, such as the Queensland Premier and the more reactionary members of the National Party of Australia in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. How can he claim, as he did in his letter to me today and confirmed in Question Time a few moments ago, that the decision taken by the Government represents a voluntary restriction on the entitlements provided and allowed under the Remuneration Tribunal when, as a result of that so-called voluntary restriction, the Treasurer has been allowed to claim travel allowances irrespective of any bona fide test or inquiry as to his principal place of residence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer I gave to the Leader of the Opposition, both in my letter to him and in this place, is in accordance with the facts. Let me look with the Leader of the Opposition at the question of the principal place of residence. The Remuneration Tribunal has provided, in its current determination on travel allowance and in similar determinations in previous years, that Ministers nominate their principal place of residence as their home base for travelling allowance purposes. On page 61 of the Tribunal's 1986 review, tabled in this Parliament-in its current report as in previous reports-it has not sought to define the term `principal place of residence'. After an inquiry from the previous Government, the Remuneration Tribunal made it clear that no close or exclusive definition of the term `principal place of residence' was possible. Mr Justice Mahoney in his advice of 17 November 1982 said:

ANSWER.PARA: I doubt that there is any single factor that can be said to be determinative or definitive of what is a principal place of residence in all cases.

I am quite happy to table that advice. It was precisely because of this lack of close definition that this Government took the decision to which I have referred. It took it in November 1983 following its election earlier that year. A further determination by the Tribunal in June of that year again did not define the principal place of residence. The decision we took was voluntarily to limit ministerial claims for travelling allowance where the Minister maintained a residence in Canberra. Obviously, the decision we took as a government was completely in line with the position that had emerged from the decisions of the Remuneration Tribunal. In terms of that decision of the Remuneration Tribunal, no one made us seek to impose any limitations upon Ministers in this place. If we had not intervened, it would have been completely consistent with the decision of the Remuneration Tribunal for it to have been open, for instance, to the Treasurer, to the extent that he worked here not only on weekdays but also on weekends-I do not think anyone would question the fact that he is often here working on weekends-to make claims beyond weekdays. In terms of the decision of the Cabinet he did not do that. His decision has been completely consistent with the decision of the Remuneration Tribunal and completely in line with the Cabinet decision of November 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the Government's recently announced policy on the relaxation of export controls on coal. Can he advise the House, first, whether the relaxation of these controls means that the Government has abandoned any control on coal exports? Secondly, what response has he received to this policy from the industry and the union movement? Thirdly, will national interest provisions be determined as a matter of priority to guide future negotiations of coal contracts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can say straightforwardly that the decision made by the Government to relax coal export controls has been taken because of the need to increase Australia's total coal export revenue. That is a decision which takes on added importance in terms of Australia's balance of payments difficulties which has sliced, as we know, some $6 billion off our national income. In those circumstances, the Government regarded it as too important to have the possible growth prospects of coal stifled. It was, in the Government's judgment, important to ensure that the marketing efforts of Australia's coal companies were not unnecessarily impeded. Let me make it clear that the decision of the Government was not made or designed to permit Australian companies to take existing market share from one another but rather to increase Australia's total share of the world coal market. The pre-existing arrangements had become impossible to administer with the Department of Trade virtually having to make a seat of the pants judgment as to what constituted negotiating parameters. We had some 40 coal companies operating in a similar number of markets-about 40-and given the increasingly volatile and competitive nature of those markets, it was becoming increasingly impossible to have any confidence that the judgment made about appropriate negotiating parameters in fact reflected the circumstances of those markets. So we made the judgment that those cumbersome procedures, which had, we thought, an increasing lack of reality and coincidence with the facts of markets, required a change.

ANSWER.PARA: It is important to remember that the Government still retains the power to examine contract terms negotiated by coal companies before granting final approval. In other words, two layers of approval have been replaced by one. If the Government is not satisfied that those contract terms are in the national interest and if it believes that a company has been simply trying to capture market share from other companies it can and will exercise its reserve power. We have been conscious of the fact, as the honourable member knows, that there would be some understandable concern as to the potential impact of these important changes. Before they were made there was some discussion by the Minister for Trade with interests concerned. We have had discussions with Caucus members, whose electorates contain mines and who could potentially be involved or concerned. Of course, we had discussions yesterday with representatives of the coal mining unions. On the return of the Minister for Trade from his eminently successful negotiations in Punta del Este he will be having further discussions with the Australian Coal Consultative Council. I am confident that, as a result of those discussions that the Minister will have with the various interests-mine owners, mine operators and mine workers-all parties in the Australian coal industry will see that the decision that has been taken by the Government is one which is not only consistent with Australia's interests, but also is calculated significantly to advance those interests while taking full cognisance of the interests of all geographical sectors in the industry in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Was he elected to government in 1983 on the promise that he would reduce the price of fuel by 3c a litre. Is it not a fact that since that time the price of fuel has been increased by 13c a litre? With 3 1/2 years down the line, will he say whether he intends to honour his commitment to the Australian people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government was elected overwhelmingly on the promise that it would undertake the recovery and the reconstruction of an Australian economy which had been left devastated by 7 1/2 years of incompetent and criminally negligent coalition rule. That was the promise that was made. We have been spectacularly successful in delivering on that promise. I suppose that if we could have just one test at this time of the success or otherwise of this Government's economic policy it would be that, if we had not been successful, those opposite would be bombarding us with questions on economic management and economic policy. If there is one single thing which unifies the commentary which is made upon the proceedings of this Parliament by those who have the responsibility of reporting on it, it is that the Opposition has consistently and singularly failed to address any questions of significance to this Government on its economic management. There has not been a question.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Treasurer and the Special Minister of State have indicated, the Opposition's tactics committees-I understand there are four of them; my God, the Opposition needs either to abolish the four it has or to get another 10-have decided that this Government has been so pre-eminently successful in the management of the Australian economy that it has not got the guts, the determination, the wit or the wisdom to address a single question on the economy. So I say to the honourable member that a government does not conduct economic policy in terms of saying: `Let us look at one element'.

What we have done is to follow the import parity pricing policy that was pursued, with good reason, by the previous Government. When we were elected in March 1983, were we or others to foresee the gyrations that took place in the international prices for oil? We have responsibly sought to adjust the import pricing policy in a way which, as far as possible in the adjustment of those prices, is revenue neutral. If there have been decisions to raise revenue they have been taken separately from our policy in regard to oil pricing. In doing that, we have therefore ensured that the basic tenet and philosophy of the IPP policy of our predecessors will be adhered to. As I have had cause to say before, in the outcome the price of petrol in this country is still amongst the lowest anywhere in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Housing and Construction. What impact will Federal funding have on meeting the demand for public housing this financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Cowan for her question. This is a most timely question as the Opposition and the Opposition spokesman on housing seem to have lost interest in the issue entirely. Indeed, the Opposition spokesman on housing seems to have sunk back into his usual torpor on this particularly important public issue. I am happy to report to the House that, as I said last Friday, this Hawke Labor Government treats housing as a high priority issue and, of course, we treat public housing as a particularly high priority issue. This Government has a real concern for the needs of the poorest in our community and for the needs of lower income earners. I point out to the House that at least 75 per cent of allocations by State governments are to recipients of social security pensions or benefits.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1986-87 this Government will direct $694m by way of grants to the States and furthermore it will allow the States, under their State Government borrowing programs, to nominate 60 per cent of their funds, or 100 per cent in the case of Western Australia and South Australia, at the concessional interest rate of 4 1/2 per cent as long as those funds are directed to the provision of public housing. I am very pleased to report to the House that it is my understanding that all States, with the exception of Tasmania, will nominate to the full extent of their entitlement. This will mean that another $582m can be added to the Federal effort of $694m by way of grants. That is 130 per cent more than the level of funds which was provided under the former Government in 1982-83. When one adds the matching State grants to that figure, all up a record figure will be directed to public housing by the Federal Government and by State governments. So ours is a really great effort in public housing.

Our policy will allow the States to add to the national rental stock some 18,000 extra units this financial year. This compares with only 8,700 units which were added to the national rental stock in 1982-83, which was the last year in office of the former Government. We will also be able, through the States, to direct over 14,000 subsidised loans to low income earners who wish to acquire their own homes this financial year. Some 22,000 new commencements will be recorded this year as a result of our public housing effort. That is the highest level of new commencements we have ever seen from public housing funding. All this adds up to a very strong public housing effort. I believe that it is a measure of the Hawke Labor Government's abiding concern for the families and single people of this nation who are in need of public housing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I add to an answer I gave yesterday and honour my promise to the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) to provide the information as soon as I could. The pamphlet advocating orgasm, masturbation and the use of marihuana and alcohol to relieve period pain, which the honourable member referred to, was, as far as can be determined, originally published in 1978 when the Commonwealth Government had responsibility for the direct funding and operational oversight of community health centres. This explains the reference to funding by the Commonwealth contained in the pamphlet. I am, of course, not suggesting that the Fraser Government approved the pamphlet. Indeed, in a review in 1980-81 the Commonwealth Department of Health objected to the reference to marihuana and to other points made in the pamphlet. The pamphlet was redrafted as a result.

ANSWER.PARA: Since 1981 direct funding and responsibility for health centres have been transferred to State governments. The redrafted version of the pamphlet makes no mention of marihuana. It says of alcohol that `a small amount taken when period pain is present helps some women'. It says of orgasm that it `relieves pelvic congestion' but it leaves it up to contemporary readers to decide how best that can be accomplished. The pamphlet was designed for women of all ages who experience period pain. The fact that copies of the original version were distributed to year 10 students at one school recently was a mistake. I am informed that the school has since destroyed all remaining copies. I also understand that the women's health centres have advised that the original version of the pamphlet should not be used and that copies should be destroyed. Insofar as the honourable member sought to offer criticism of the Commonwealth-State national campaign against drug abuse, I simply point out that all governments in this country are mounting a concerted effort to highlight to people of all ages, but particularly young people, the dangers of drug abuse.

PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many post office agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities. They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport. We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew,Mr Beale,Dr Blewett,Mr Blunt,Mr Cadman,Mr Carlton,Mr Conquest,Mr Cowan,Mrs Darling,Mr Drummond,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Tim Fischer,Mr Hawker,Mr Howard,Mr Kent,Mr Milton,Mr O'Neil,Mr Porter,Mr Reith,Mr Ian Robinson,Mr Shack,Mr Slipper,Dr Watson and Mr Wright.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hollis,Mr Kent,Mr Milton and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce divisions in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Hawker and Mr Reith.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker,Mr Kent and Mr O'Neil.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned plead that the Parliament implement pro-family policies. In particular we appeal for:
1. the retention of the present graduated assessment system for payment of the Family Allowance;
2. indexation of the Family Allowance in order to keep pace with inflation;

3. an increase of 3.7% in the Family Allowance benefit to return it to 11.5% of the Average Award Wage (making it similar in value to the 11.5% of the Basic Wage when Child Endowment was first introduced by the Chifley Government in 1941).
4. retention of the Dependent Spouse Rebate and the amount of the Dependent Spouse Rebate adjusted so that it is equal in value to the tax-free threshold allowed when calculating taxable income.
Your petitioners therefore humble pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Tests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that-

1. A cessation of the testing of nuclear weapons would break the cycle of research, development and deployment of nuclear weapons and prevent the acquisition of new and ever more lethal weapons of mass destruction. It would thus be a major and significant step towards ending the arms race and beginning the disarmament process; and
2. The Soviet Union has extended its unilateral moratorium on nuclear weapons testing until August 6 this year and has again invited the United States to cease its nuclear testing program.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Australian Government to put the strongest pressure on the United States Government to join the Soviet Union's nuclear test ban.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Jenkins,Mr Kent and Mr Milton.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent,Mr Milton and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth
1. That the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 is having a detrimental effect on the car industry generally in South Australia, and more particularly, on employment in that industry.

2. The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 contains many anomalies, inconsistencies and mistakes in drafting and its administrative implementation is an unwarranted burden on Australian businesses and the Australian taxpayer.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this House repeal as a matter of utmost urgency this regressive legislation which imposes a disincentive to economic and employment growth, thereby jeopardising the well-being and living standards of all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The Fringe Benefits Tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The Fringe Benefits Tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it, and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this legislation, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights
that the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education
that the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate
that the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron and Mr Hawker.

PETITION.TITLE: Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners have grave concern about recent changes in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act of 1966 which deny basic rights which have been a cornerstone of the English and Australian law for over seven hundred years. We are speaking of the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and the right of an individual to defend himself against his accusers. This concern has come to light during recent extradition proceedings against Messrs Hempel and Etheredge in Western Australia.

We are concerned that because judicial protection of these basic rights has been excluded from the Act, refugees, migrants, Australian overseas travellers, and visitors are at risk when they have been to (or come from) countries where the norms and practices of human rights and civil liberties are below traditionally accepted Australian standards.

We the undersigned petitioners, therefore urge the Government to re-examine the Extradition (Foreign States) Act (as amended in 1985), and amend the current Act so that the rights of the accused are once again judicially protected in Australia.

In addition, we urge the government to refrain from entering into any further extradition treaties or proceedings under the current Act until the process of re-examination and amendment of the Act has occurred.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Campbell and Mr Drummond.

PETITION.TITLE: First International Earth Repair Year
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That deterioration of the total global environment is continuing at an increasing rate; that important environmental resources vital to human livelihood such as trees, soil and water are decreasing at an alarming rate; that there is a need for educating all people to assume a greater responsibility for the conservation, sustainable use and maintenance of vital resources; that dynamic and active initiatives are needed to conserve and renew the total environment; and that protecting, conserving and repairing the Earth can unite all people and nations in co-operative action for survival;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will:
Propose to the United Nations General Assembly at its 41st Session in September 1986 that 1988 be proclaimed the ``First International Earth Repair Year''
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton and Dr Harry Edwards.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Hawke Government should-
1. Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices
2. Not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
3. Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Party Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker and Mr Reith.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and honourable members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned residents of Australia totally reject any move to cut funding to Australia-wide English as a Second Language programs in schools.
We request that the Australian government restore funding to the 1985 level in the 1986-87 Budget.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hollis and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Glen Waverley Rehabilitation Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that the phasing down and eventual closure of the services of the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Centre at Glen Waverley will be detrimental to the rehabilitation of disabled Australian citizens;
(2) that the Glen Waverley Rehabilitation Centre is `purpose' built and its loss would deprive disabled Australian citizens of a unique multi-million dollar facility;
(3) that the essential accommodation for disabled Australian citizens will no longer be available.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
(1) that the phasing down of the services of the Glen Waverley Rehabilitation Centre be reversed immediately;
(2) that the one hundred and four bed residential facility be fully utilised immediately;
(3) that sufficient funding is provided by the Commonwealth Department of Community Services to operate the Centre at full capacity.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Chernobyl Nuclear Disaster
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concern to Australian citizens asks that:
1. The Australian Government exert pressure on Moscow to-
(a) Allow the International Atomic Energy Commission full expert investigation of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster and its human consequences;
(b) Allow Australian Ukrainians to send medical aid to family and friends in Soviet Ukraine; and,
(c) Allow free communication between Australian and Soviet Ukrainians.
2. The Australian Government-
(a) Launch a public appeal to help the Chernobyl victims;
(b) Support the removal of Russian nuclear weapons out of Ukraine;
(c) Support the decolonization of the USSR so that captive nations like Ukraine and the Baltic states are not exploited for Soviet Russian nuclear purposes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Bill of Rights is not supported by the people of Australia, and calls on the Government to:
Delay proclamation of the Bill until all matters of contention are settled by national referenda, and that:
(1) Matters of States rights, property rights, rights of the newborn, the right not to belong to unions, among other issues, have not been submitted to the people of Australia to decide, and that;
(2) No Australian Bill of Rights should depend on any foreign convention for its basis in Australian law.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Wollongong Area Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we the citizens of the Illawarra Region condemn the decision to close the Wollongong office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs
And that we respectfully request that this decision be reversed immediately.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Film Censorship Board
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will legislate, or act in accordance with the present legislation, to replace the current members of the Film Censorship Board who have admitted to Senator Harradine on 12th December 1984, as reported in the Senate Select Committee on Video Material, (see attached extracts), that they are not applying either the blasphemy or obscenity tests as required under the provisions of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations, and that these persons be replaced by persons who will apply these and the other related tests in accordance with the said Regulations.
Your petitioners humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the Government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor Government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25% of Average Weekly Earnings;
2. That the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and the subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted.
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the hardship caused by present provisions of the Assets Test to those people who own small holdings of land on which their home is erected. Your petitioners therefore request that the provisions of the Assets Test be modified by an increase in the threshold amount which applicants for pensions are allowed to own before the Assets Test renders them ineligible for a pension.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That Labor's capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, tax on lump sum superannuation and assets test are an unwarranted burden on the people of Australia, have contributed to the national economic crisis and the anomalies in the legislation are causing confusion and anger amongst all sections of the Australian community.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of Labor's Assets Test, Labor's Capital Gains Tax, Labor's Fringe Benefit Tax and Labor's tax on lump sum superannuation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Standards and Screening Hours
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament becomes aware that the Public has no legal right to influence the setting of Standards for Television Programming, that we deplore the new Standards which came into force on 1st February, and that we call on Parliament to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, section 16 (2), so that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, when determining Television Standards, and screening hours, shall consult with the Australian people:
because at present the Tribunal is compelled by law to consult only with television stations on these matters,
because the new standards are a result of such consultation, and have already been implemented without public discussion,
because the new Standards are ambiguous, and without definition,
because the new Standards are composed of modifying terms which circumvent the proscriptions,
because the media is only motivated by aspirations of pecuniary superiority,
because, in contrast, the public is only motivated by their wish to exercise pastoral care over the nurturing home environment of their children,
because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe extreme importance to ``the storyline' of a film screened,

because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe total unimportance to the effects of viewing, especially violent films, on the young, the impressionable, the immature, the unstable, or the socially disadvantaged,
because we refuse to accept the media-imposed assessment of community standards,
and because we wish to impart our demand to be consulted, our demand to have legal status in decision-making, and the right to counsel those whose decisions so deeply affect our homes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest attention, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Government should cancel the Fringe Benefits Tax they intend to impose on businesses throughout Australia because:
(1) The tax discriminates against charitable organisations, sports clubs, private schools and religious organisations:
(2) The tax will mean employees around Australia will suffer reductions in their remuneration packages:
(3) The Bill places another impossible burden of paperwork on small business:
(4) The Bill is absurd in its application to Government employees, who now constitute 32% of the workforce.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament House.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education.
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly impact on pensioners.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Wollongong Area Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the closure of the Wollongong area office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

2. That the impact of the closure of the office in Wollongong will be particularly felt by the non-english speaking migrants and community at large from Shoalhaven to Hellensberg and as far as Wingecarribee and Wollondilly.

Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to ensure that the area office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in Wollongong be kept operational and fully staffed.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that:
in this International Year of Peace, 1986, the world needs a nuclear test moratorium by the united States, the Soviet Union, France and other nuclear-testing powers
that such a moratorium would create a favourable climate and basis for the negotiation of a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
that such a Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty would
be the first vital step to nuclear disarmament
impede the development of new nuclear weapons
decrease the reliance upon an unstable nuclear strategy
inhibit the spread of nuclear weapons.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Australian Government be urged to:
1. Use its influence with the United States Government to encourage it to join the moratorium on nuclear testing begun by the Soviet Union on 6 August 1985.
2. Use its influence in all forums to encourage other nuclear nations to join the Nuclear Test Moratorium.
3. Use its influence in all forums to encourage on nuclear nations to demand the establishment of a Nuclear Test Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Medicare Office, Lalor/Thomastown
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

that the current policy pursued by the Hawke Government is causing an intolerable increase in home loan interest rates beyond the capacity of families to pay.

that the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.

Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag remain sacrosanct from change''.

Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to reverse this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
