DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The urgent need in Australia for an industrial relations system which makes all parties equal before the law and provides incentives for enterprise-based productivity gains.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), pursued a matter of public importance dealing with restrictive work practices. Because the Opposition regards reform of our archaic, outdated, unworkable and increasingly backward-looking industrial relations system as about the most important challenge in the whole economic area, we again bring forward for discussion as a matter of urgency the reform of Australia's industrial relations system.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday my colleague the Deputy Leader reminded the Parliament essentially of the humbug and the death-bed repentance of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the subject of restrictive work practices. All of us do well to remind ourselves, every time we think of the Australian economy, of two things about the principal economic helmsmen of Australia at present. We ought to remind ourselves that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is the man who destroyed our AAA credit rating, and we ought to remind ourselves that the man who did more than any other living Australian to entrench the archaic restrictive work practices that he now rails against was none other than the present Prime Minister when he led the Australian Council of Trade Unions. If ever a man behaved as though Australia were an economic island, it did not matter what the rest of the world thought and it did not matter how uncompetitive the Australian economy became, it was R. J. L. Hawke in the days when he led the ACTU. The primary producers and the exporters of Australia often watched in anguish as their produce rotted on the wharves of this country, until the Leader of the ACTU deigned that it was politically and industrially satisfactory to intervene. That produce would rot on the wharves of this nation until he saw it as being in his self-interest to intervene to settle those disputes.

Yesterday we were reminded of what a humbug the Prime Minister is on the subject of work practices. Does anybody in this House really believe that we would be having a conference on restrictive work practices tomorrow, attended by the Prime Minister, if it had not been for the Robe River dispute? Whatever people's views may be about the precise methodology of Robe River, the fact nonetheless remains that the so-called troglodytes, lunatics, economic destroyers and traitors are the very people who caused and helped to cause this death-bed repentance of the Prime Minister on the subject of restrictive work practices. I think we all ought to remember that.

The most remarkable thing about this whole debate is the way in which the agenda has moved in favour of policies advocated by the Opposition over the last couple of years. I can remember saying in September 1983, when I was Deputy Leader of the Opposition, at the National Press Club, in my reply to the Budget, that I believe that it was about time Mr Justice Higgins was turned on his head. Mr Justice Higgins, be it remembered, was the person who wrote the famous Harvester judgment which entrenched the principle of comparative wage justice in the Australian industrial relations experience. I was arguing at that time for a more flexible industrial relations system, one that took greater account of capacity to pay, one that recognised the value of enterprise-based agreements, and one that essentially rejected the notion that unions are entitled to a privileged position above the law. Our ideas then-and increasingly-were rejected by the Government as being irrelevant.

The high water mark of that rejection, of course, was reached just over 12 months ago when, to the sound of cymbals and drums, the accord mark 2 was negotiated. I well remember the renegotiation of that accord, because we were told by everybody, from the Prime Minister down, that it was the greatest economic achievement since Adam Smith wrote The Wealth of Nations, that it was the most brilliant economic achievement that anybody had ever achieved. We heard remarks such as this by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), who is at the table:

Ratification of the accord would see a consolidation and a strengthening of existing progress that would firmly entrench the accord as the only viable long term approach to economic and social policy in Australia.
That is what he said a little over 12 months ago. Again, on 15 October 1985, he stated:
The Australian people must realise that because the accord is there-
and listen to these pearls of economic and industrial wisdom of 15 October 1985-
we have the capacity to adjust to that devaluation-
the Minister was talking about the devaluation of 1985-
without suffering a recession of the economy and a loss of economic and employment growth.

We all know what has happened. We have had three more debilitating devaluations since that statement was made. The economy has technically gone into recession and we are now witnessing a rise in unemployment and a loss of international competitiveness. So much for the achievement of accord mark 2.

Principally, I want to talk about what we believe should be the real alternative in industrial relations in Australia, and we ought in the process remind ourselves of the myths that have surrounded the accord. If ever an economic theory was shrouded in myth and legend, it is the prices and incomes accord. The Government keeps telling us that unit labour costs have fallen and that we have become more competitive. However, the chart that I hold tells otherwise. It shows that our unit labour costs, compared with those of our major trading partners, have become steadily worse since March 1983. However, the Prime Minister keeps tramping the country with his cohorts saying that there has been a 7 per cent fall in real wages over the past 3 1/2 years.

The Prime Minister does not tell us, of course, that 5 per cent of that 7 per cent fall occurred in 1983-84, and was due to the beneficial effects of the Fraser Government's wages pause, a pause that the Prime Minister tried to stop. He conspired with the then President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions to bring down the former leader of the Labor Party and to delay its implementation. He does not tell us anything of that. Instead, the Prime Minister runs around the country telling us how industrial disputation has lessened under the accord. He tells us all of that but he does not tell us that other countries that have entirely different industrial relations systems have also enjoyed a more beneficial industrial relations climate over the past 3 1/2 years. He does not tell us that industrial disputes in that period have declined 60 per cent in the United States, 50 per cent in France, 80 per cent in Italy, 60 per cent in Canada and 80 per cent in West Germany. He would have us believe that the only country where there has been any decline in industrial disputes over the past 3 1/2 years is Australia, and that all of it is due to his brilliance and that of the prices and incomes accord.

The reality is that without the accord there would have been an equivalent fall in the number of industrial disputes in this country, and that it has been more a consequence of the high levels of unemployment and the economic difficulties of the western industrialised world that there has been such a fall during the relevant period. In the wake of the failure of the accord we have various flavours of the month, and the great flavour of the month now is Sweden. The Opposition welcomes that because a Labor government will always embrace Sweden as an example. Sweden is the corporate state par excellence. It has a taxation level which is 51 per cent of gross domestic product and an expenditure level that is 64 per cent of GDP. I can only say that I hope that Sweden is the flavour of every month from now until the end of the year. We shall embrace the analogy of Sweden.

Our real need is to have a more flexible approach to industrial relations that asserts the fundamental principle that no segment of the Australian community should be above the law. When we criticise trade union power, we do not criticise the existence of unions. We do not argue with the legitimate industrial aspirations of the Australian trade union movement. We have no quarrel with them. The unions are part of the Australian community. However, we assert most vigorously that no segment of the Australian community should be above the law.

For that reason, we reject the Minister's declared intention-I will be interested if he denies it-to introduce the reforms recommended by the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. The implementation of those recommendations would further entrench the privileged position of the trade union leaders. It would establish the view that trade union leaders are an elite, above and beyond the laws of this country. The Minister still wants to abolish the secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act. If that assertion of mine is wrong, I challenge him to deny that it is still Government policy to abolish section 45D of the Trade Practices Act-the section which I inserted, as Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in a previous Government, and the section which made Mudginberri the triumph for individual entrepreneurial struggle against union might that it undoubtedly was and will go down in the folklore of this country as having been.

But above that, we also need an approach to industrial relations at an enterprise level that goes over and beyond the union structure. We need, as Charlie Fitzgibbon acknowledged in his very worthwhile paper to the Economic Planning Advisory Council, more Lincoln Electrics. The Minister may not like Lincoln Electrics Company (Aust.) Pty Ltd, and Charlie may not like it; but we need a few more of those. We also need to recognise that in order to lift the productivity of this country, we need a greater element of co-operation and agreement between employers and employees. But we do not need that at a bureaucratic trade union level. We do not need it as the accord states we do or as the Government believes we do. We shall not achieve it by getting the ACTU and the employer organisations together. We shall achieve it increasingly through providing incentives through the tax system and through encouraging profit sharing arrangements and employee share ownership arrangements. We need to encourage a greater degree of co-operation at an enterprise, a work place and a shop floor level.

That is why the Opposition's alternative industrial relations policy says a number of things about small business, because it is in the small business area that a start can really be made. Small businesses, by their very nature, are not highly unionised, and that gives a flexibility at the work place level that is absent in a larger plant. Small businesses, by their very nature, encourage greater exchange and communication between the employer and his employees. For that reason, we say that every firm in Australia that employs fewer than 50 people should be free to make its own bargains, subject only to the payment of an hourly minimum rate of remuneration. That is the foundation of the new flexibility that we can breathe into the Australian industrial relations system, because we are talking about approximately 40 to 45 per cent of the total private sector work force of this country.

Over a period of three years in our first term of office, if we can deregulate and free up all the firms in Australia that employ fewer than 50 people, we will have brought about an industrial relations revolution which will literally transform the economic outlook of the entire community. That is why that is an underpinning of our alternative industrial relations policy.

I conclude by saying to the Minister and to the Government that we welcome this debate on industrial relations, we are greatly encouraged that Sweden is the flavour of the month, and we are more convinced than ever that the path to real reform lies down the deregulatory route that we have so vigorously argued over the last 3 1/2 years.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, likewise, welcomes this debate, initiated by the Opposition, because we believe the Opposition is on incredibly weak ground when it comes to industrial relations. Its record in government was abysmal. Its record when in opposition in trying to formulate an effective policy is just as bad, and its policy now that it has one, which was very briefly alluded to by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), is even worse.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset let me nail the great lie which is being perpetrated by the Opposition in almost every speech that is made by its leadership. The Opposition would have the Australian people believe that the fact that, after three years of extremely strong economic and employment growth, this country has gone into a period of lower growth in the economy, lesser growth in employment and some rise in unemployment, is due to some defect in the industrial relations system. We totally reject that great lie which continually comes from the Opposition. There is simply no truth in it whatsoever. The fact is that we have had an industrial relations system operating over the last three years which has coincided with record growth of the economy, record growth in employment and, of course, a tremendous reduction in the level of industrial disputes. There has been an enormous improvement in the industrial relations environment in this country since this Government came to office.

We now face a situation in which economic prospects are not as bright as they were over the previous three years not because there has been any sudden defect exposed in the industrial relations system or because our wages policy has gone awry, but because we as a nation have faced the fact that we have been beset by a tremendous fall in our export prices, particularly for our commodities. Given the fact that commodities are the overwhelming proportion of our exports, that has given us a balance of payments problem which necessarily involves a very considerable adjustment in the Australian economy. Part of that adjustment is lesser growth of the economy, lesser growth of employment and some period of rising unemployment.

That is a process we have to go through not because of any fault in the industrial relations system, not because of any failure of the Government, not because of any failure of the accord or the wages policy, not because the trade unions have gone berserk or the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has been totally irresponsible, but simply because something has been imposed upon this nation by the rest of the world to which we as a nation must adjust. That is the basic reality which must be understood by all Australians. Certainly, any fair minded person would acknowledge that that is the situation.

It is just unbelievable that the Opposition continues to try to perpetrate the myth that our economic situation is the result of some defect in the industrial relations system and that if only we threw away the present industrial relations system and grabbed the one from the United States of America or somewhere else we would suddenly have a new nirvana with a rapidly growing output in employment and higher standards of living. It is an absolute nonsense to perpetrate that kind of belief in the Australian electorate. I am sure that the electorate is far too intelligent to swallow that great lie which continually comes from the Opposition.

The Opposition's industrial relations policy is now, as it was when those opposite were in government, in a terrible mess. On the other hand, as I have said, the Government has been able to point to tremendous achievements. Let me very quickly remind the House again of those achievements. In the last three years we have had economic growth in the region of 5 per cent per year compared with an average of 2 per cent achieved by the Fraser Government. We have had growth in employment of 650,000, the fastest rate of job growth in the Western world in the past two years. Industrial disputes have been reduced to less than half of the average level under the Fraser Government. We have seen real wages fall by 5 per cent in a period of strong economic growth which, of course, contrasts totally with what has happened in previous periods of strong economic growth. There has been a fall of 7 per cent in real unit labour costs, something that no other country in the Western world has achieved in that period. We have also seen a return to more normal levels of profitability. These are results which the Fraser Government never looked like achieving at any time. Those opposite are massively envious of the fact that such results have been achieved by a Labor government through an accord operating with the trade union movement, something which they could never have achieved.

Let me make the point that real wages have fallen by 5 per cent. Over the same period in the United States real wages declined by about half a per cent but in West Germany growth was near 4 per cent, in Japan it was just under 6 per cent and in the United Kingdom-this is a very relevant comparison for us to make because of the similarity of the trade union structure in that country-there has been growth despite a 13 per cent unemployment level. We have seen growth in real wages of 10.5 per cent over the past three years in that country. That is one of the reasons it still has 13 per cent unemployment, and this is despite the strong anti-union stance of the Thatcher Government and an array of anti-union legislation which has been brought in to break the unions. It still resulted in 10.5 per cent real wage growth over the past three years.

The Leader of the Opposition made some international comparisons regarding industrial disputes. Over the past three years, the average time lost in industrial disputes in Australia has fallen by 75 per cent which compares to a growth of 22 per cent in the United Kingdom. So with all the array of anti-union legislation that the Thatcher Government has armed itself with and 13 per cent unemployment, industrial disputation still increased by 22 per cent. If we look at international comparisons we should realise that in the United Kingdom the comparison-which is most appropriate to us-is a very invidious one. I say to those who say that the United Kingdom has a better system that Australia fares infinitely better with a massive reduction in industrial disputation. My Department has done some research which shows that of nine Western countries Australia has recorded the largest fall in time lost in industrial disputes.

Briefly I compare that enormously good record with that achieved by the Fraser Government. As I mentioned, it had growth in the economy of 2 per cent. It had a virtual fiasco rather than a wages policy. It vacillated between support for full indexation which did not last very long-about three months-partial indexation, no indexation, collective bargaining, and a wage freeze. Its crowning achievement was the disastrous metal trades adjustment in 1981-82 where average earnings rose by almost 17 per cent. That, of course, led us to an increase in real unit labour costs of 16.5 per cent in 1982, which was 10 per cent higher than that of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. It was 10 per cent higher than that of our major trading partners. It was an enormous blow-out. The Leader of the Opposition in the course of his speech had the hide to say that there has been some slight excess in the rate of increase in wages in Australia over that achieved by our trading partners over the past three years. In fact, in 1982 when the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer we had a massive blow-out which infinitely damaged our competitive position compared to our trading partners.

If we look at what has happened in the wages area we will see that over the past three years award rates have increased by 5.1 per cent under this Government compared to an average of 10.9 per cent under the Fraser Government. Average weekly earnings have increased by 7.1 per cent compared to 11.6 per cent average under the Fraser Government. There has been a tremendous decline in real unit labour costs as I have mentioned. In relation to industrial disputes, the average working days lost under the Fraser Government was three million days per annum compared to an average of 1.3 million under this Government-less than half. Time lost peaked at a disastrous 44.7 million days in the year ending May 1980 under the Fraser Government compared to 1.4 million days in the year ending May this year. On any comparison of the record of industrial relations of this Government and the record of the previous Government, one can only be staggered at the difference-our performance has been infinitely better. The Opposition has been madly scrabbling around trying to gather some form of coherent wages and industrial relations policy. We have seen it go through all sorts of convolutions trying to achieve that policy. It came up with some sort of patched up compromise in 1984 which it abandoned after a series of wrangles where it publicly clashed with what the policy ought to be. Even the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr), who was Chairman of the Opposition's industrial relations committee at the end of 1985, resigned because he said that the opting out proposal that it was looking at was constitutionally unobtainable, that it would act as a pacesetter for awards and that it would produce a worse wage outcome for the economy, which of course it would. Even when its new policy was completed it showed a total lack of confidence in it and concern at the likely public reaction to it, by producing a hit list of businessmen-which I revealed in this House-who had to be neutralised along with journalists before the policy could be released.

When we look at this pathetic policy which the Leader of the Opposition says will open up a new era and provide a revolution in industrial relations we see how laughable it is. Economically it is utterly irresponsible because it has no wages policy in it at all. The Opposition simply says that it will encourage everyone to have voluntary agreements. If it is going to encourage voluntary agreements and if it is going to undertake the kind of action it wants in respect of wages and conditions, in those areas where there is strong bargaining power we will see parties reach agreements which will involve substantial increases in wages and conditions of employment. There then will be enormous pressure for those conditions to flow on. That has been the basic element of the Australian economy, which has so marked industrial relations in the past couple of decades, and which the accord directly addressed. The accord directly addressed that element by saying that we have to contain that kind of thing, and we have contained it in a way which has meant that we have been tremendously successful in redressing many of the fundamental imbalances in this economy.

But the Opposition has also produced a policy in relation to voluntary agreements which is constitutionally unworkable. Do not tell me that it is not because even Brent Davis of the Australian Chamber of Commerce agreed in an article in Australian Business that it is constitutionally unworkable. He is from the far New Right and if he says it is unworkable, the Opposition has real problems. It is unconstitutional because to provide that parties can establish their own voluntary agreements to set their own wages and conditions of employment is not possible under the conciliation and arbitration power because that power is founded on the existence of an industrial dispute extending beyond one State. Therefore employers and employees can only agree to conciliation and arbitration for dispute settlement and Parliament can legislate only to provide for agreements prescribing dispute settling procedures by conciliation and arbitration. A voluntary agreement could not simply prescribe wages and conditions of employment as proposed in the Opposition's policy.

The Opposition has also proposed that agreements will provide for relevant award rates of pay to apply to avoid the potential for sweated workshops. This simply cannot be guaranteed as Commonwealth legislation cannot require particular provisions to be included in agreements. Therefore, voluntary agreements would be capable of overriding all minimum standards prescribed in Federal or State awards and State legislation. One cannot say that there is this bottom line of an award rate because one simply cannot prescribe that. There is no constitutional power to do that.

The Liberals also propose that part of an employment relationship be award covered and the other part be agreement related. Under the conciliation and arbitration power this is extremely doubtful as it is necessary to incorporate all industrial matters involved in the employment relationship into a single instrument. The Opposition also proposes to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to prohibit the Commission having regard to the provisions of voluntary agreements. Again this is highly doubtful as Parliament cannot direct the Commission in its dispute settling role. There are a number of other reasons why this policy is uncon- stitutional.

The Opposition, as part of its aim of achieving government, has paraded as its No. 1 plank a policy based on the myth that industrial relations are the basic problem in the country, but the No. 1 element of that No. 1 plank is totally unconstitutional. The Opposition simply cannot bring it into effect. The Opposition has no power to bring it into effect, unless it is going to try to use some other constitutional arrangements, which will break new ground for the Opposition and will also mean incomplete coverage and certainly will not bring about the kind of industrial relations revolution which it says it will achieve with this policy. We are seeing extreme naivete from the Opposition in industrial relations. It comes through in almost everything it says. The fact that it comes up with a policy that is constitutionally invalid demonstrates more than anything else the sheer naivete and lack of knowledge about industrial relations of this Opposition and its unfitness to be the government of this country.

We find that the average for the OECD trading partners will be 4 1/2 per cent; not 6 per cent. Excise duty on motor spirit and diesel is reduced by 3.699c per litre to 20.185c per litre. The reductions for aviation gasoline and aviation kerosene are 3.114c per litre and 2.958c per litre respectively. For other kerosene, fuel oil and heating oil the reduction is 0.767c per litre. I would also advise honourable members that rates of diesel fuel rebate decrease in conjunction with these duty changes. Vehicles imported in each of these quota periods will attract a general tariff rate of 60.5 per cent, three percentage points higher than the base quota rate.

The final change in proposals No. 16 involves the rate of duty to apply to under-quota imports of passenger motor vehicles qualifying for developing country preference. In accordance with the principles of the revised Australian system of tariff preferences for imports from developing countries which formed part of the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1986, all new quotas are to have a margin of preference of five percentage points. This is a change from the 7.5 percentage points applying to quotas already in existence at the time of implementation of the revised developing countries preference scheme. Summaries of the alterations contained in these proposals have been prepared and are being circulated to honourable members. I commend the proposals to the house.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is probably no more significant area affecting the welfare of a large percentage of the Australian people than their superannuation benefit. Superannuation applies in a number of different sectors-in the private sector through funds to which individual employees make their contribution; in the Services, where there is membership either through the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits or the Defence Forces Retirement and Death Benefits schemes; and in the Commonwealth Public Service where there is a Commonwealth superannuation fund. SPEECH.PARA: The Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 specifically applies to the superannuation entitlement of Commonwealth and defence personnel. It is a very significant sector of the community, and it is a sector which, perhaps more than many others, has been led to believe by successive governments that its superannuation entitlement was a fundamental reason for its retaining that type of employment. We all know that many Commonwealth public servants, particularly as they reach the middle to senior stages of their careers, recognise that the pay available outside their present employment would be significantly better than it is in the Commonwealth Public Service. If that applies in the civil service, how much more does it apply in the Services? There, unfortunately, we have had a progressive deterioration in the terms and conditions of employment. I will say something in a moment about the number of people who are retiring or resigning prematurely from the service.

The reality is that, sadly, in our two major capital cities on the east cost-Sydney and Melbourne-the respect that was traditionally given to people in uniform is not as it used to be. There has been all this arrant nonsense pursued by members of the Labor Party, and particularly by the socialist left of the Labor Party, in peace studies, saying the defence forces are out there promoting war while there is another element out there promoting peace. That is absolute nonsense. The reality is that the Australian Defence Force is in the front line of promoting peace for Australia, of trying to defend this country and of trying to ensure, wherever Australia's national interest runs, that there is security and that that security can be obtained by maximising the deterrent impact of what would happen to any potential aggressor.

I feel very sad when I see photographs, as I did only a couple of days ago, of some absolute miscreant-a Mickey Mouse terrorist-putting his own life at risk. But never mind his own life; he was putting the lives of others at risk in trying to demonstrate against the presence in Australian waters of visitors for the Royal Australian Navy's seventy-fifth anniversary. Those Mickey Mouse terrorists affect the lives of innocent people just as much as any terrorist in France or anyone who tries to blow up some installation around the world or to hijack an aircraft. They are trying to get personal publicity and are putting at risk the lives of policemen, of other innocent bystanders-the people out there in their water craft-and of people aboard those ships, many of whom are distinguished overseas visitors to this country, and all of whom are here, not because they wish us ill, but because they are members of an alliance with Australia to try to preserve for Australians the opportunity for peace.

Therefore, I feel very strongly that the circumstances of those in uniform and the fact that they are not given the high recognition which I believe they deserve need to be put into perspective when one looks at this legislation. There are other elements within the terms and conditions of service personnel which have deteriorated and which the Labor Party in government generally tends to play down. Of course, Labor members are trying to make big fellows of themselves and their concern for the Defence Force. They talk about the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, and then they withdraw our defence attaches from the entire region that affects us. They talk about the Dibb report and set a 10-year no-threat horizon. That 10-year no-threat horizon guarantees that Australia could find itself totally disadvantaged because the options that should be available for mounting a reasonable defence deterrent or a defence retaliation will be limited, because the program of Dibb is to make sure that our force is reduced more and more and that we have only a minimal deterrent capability related to low-level insurgencies.

The combination of all those factors shows that superannuation is about the one element of the defence forces that gives to them some greater benefit than that available perhaps in other sectors, although, as I shall explain in a moment, even that is questionable. But one thing that people need to understand is that, at a time when the superannuation entitlement of the defence forces is so important, because all those other factors have deteriorated, this Government has mounted a constant attack against that superannuation benefit. Yet before the 1983 election, the then shadow Minister for Defence, who is now the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes), said that he guaranteed that there would be no change affecting DFRDB or DFRB entitlement implemented by a Labor government. It is like all the other promises, including the one that there would be no capital gains tax. Remember that litany of lies? They have all been there from the Labor Party, and this incompetent Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who is out there daily berating us about the state of the economy, cannot even get his sums right. What makes superannuation even more important to service people is that, unlike members of the civilian work force, they have an obligation to leave their chosen profession earlier than everyone else in the community. They are not leaving the Service because they are fed up with their careers. It is not because they are unable to make a worthwhile contribution. But the deliberate policy of governments has always been to try to attract and retain younger generations in the Services, because the nature of the warrior obligation is essentially for young men and women. We see that premature retirement for a 20-year man, a nine-year man or a six-year man or woman is such that there should be a greater than normal benefit for those who retire and there should be a carrot instead of a stick when dealing with the inducement of superannuation and when considering the impact that it has on service personnel.

The tenure of occupancy of their professional career is shorter than for civilian careers. Generally, they are paid less than their civilian equivalents and they are certainly paid less than their civil service equivalents. For that reason, we are very concerned about the moves announced in the Budget which have now been followed by the legislation that is before the House.

What I want to do first, in looking at this legislation, is to look at what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said and what the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) said, because this will show one of the other typical deceit patterns of Labor in office. Accordingly, at the next National Wage Case when the combined 4.0 per cent movement in the March and June quarter Consumer Price Index will be considered, the Government will argue-
will argue, mind you, Mr Deputy Speaker-
to the Arbitration Commission that the proposed increase in wages be cut by 2 per cent.

It will not be something that is implemented in the Budget; it will be a case that is presented, perhaps persuasively, but there will be an opportunity for the trade unions to present a counter point of view. Let us look at the Minister's second reading speech. Of course, he is the Minister who, we remember, had some problems with Jeremy Cordeaux at 5DN.

TALK.START.PARA: —Scoop.
—He is known as `Scoop'. That is right. In his speech he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, as announced in the Budget Speech-
I have just read the relevant part of the Budget Speech. I ask those who are listening to balance what the Treasurer said with what the Minister said. He continued:
. . . the 2 per cent wage discount recently applied to wages . . .

It has not been applied to wages; it will be argued. The Minister stated in his second reading speech that it has been applied to wages. That is a total falsity. It is not correct that it has been applied to wages. It is a submission that is to be made to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is one that is arguable and it is one against which the Australian Council of Trade Unions can present a case and will present a case. If we are to believe it, it will certainly be mirrored against other demands that are currently being made in the negotiations of this ridiculous accord mark 3 that seems to be high on the Government's present agenda. But the Minister stated:
. . . the 2 per cent wage discount recently applied to wages is to be extended to government superannuation benefits . . .

The reality is that what has happened is that the Government has introduced legislation in advance of consideration by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It has set a date, 10 October 1986, for the commencement of this legislation, which is in advance of the consideration by the Arbitration Commission-in the words of the Treasurer in his Budget Speech-at the next national wage case. It is applying it in such a way that legislatively there can be no presentation by any service pensioner, any Commonwealth pensioner, of his side of the story.

I have tried to set out briefly the concerns that I have about the importance of superannuation for defence people. It is absolutely critical, because all the other benefits of the Defence Force have just about gone. This Government, day by day, erodes those conditions. The DFRDB and DFRB entitlements were seen as some inducement for those highly qualified, highly skilled non-commissioned officers and officers, who are absolutely critical for the Defence Force, to remain in the Australian Defence Force. But what does the Government do? In advance of consideration by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and without there being any opportunity for argument, the Government has decided that their pensions will be discounted as of 10 October 1986 to the levels that would have applied if the increase in July 1986 had been based on an increase of 7.2 per cent instead of the consumer price index increase of 9.2 per cent. The whole reason for this is to ensure that superannuitants are penalised.

I have said before that this Government has consistently attacked superannuation. We used to provide a very worthwhile personal income tax deduction. It was an incentive for people to belong to superannuation schemes. We had the idea that superannuation was a good thing. There are many people in the community who would wish during their working years to set some funds aside to try to have a benefit when they actually retire. The whole concept of superannuation, we thought, was worthy of encouragement. The Government has removed the tax concession. The obligation of service personnel is such that frequently they have to move from one place to another every two or three years. They do not even have an opportunity to buy a home. So the idea of commutation of the pension, we thought, was worth while.

What has the Government done? It has introduced that penal tax rate. It then says: `We have made a bit of an adjustment so that people are not that much worse off'. Firstly, it took about 12 months before the adjustment was introduced; secondly, people are still penalised by the additional tax that they are called on to pay; and, thirdly, as I have mentioned, because they retire earlier than the average person in civilian employment, they are unduly penalised. They are paying at a higher rate because they are almost exclusively under 55 years of age when they step down from service life. The whole purpose of that commutation of pension was to give them a lump sum of money to buy a house, to set up in business, to start up as small businessmen. But this Government is not interested in assisting people to do that. It has always had the attitude which was expressed today by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West), who extolled the virtues of public housing. What he should be doing is extolling the opportunity for people to invest in homes, to attract savings. The Government wonders what is wrong with the country. It knocks people who try to save. What it ought to be doing, if it is going to put money in that area, is encouraging people to buy their own homes, to encourage Australians to do what people in other countries are doing, so that they have a bit of a nest egg.

Quite obviously, a comparison can be made between Australia and Japan. Japan encourages savings. Japan's yen is strong. Australia's dollar is weak. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said during the discussion of the matter of public importance earlier this afternoon, the world's best Treasurer has presided over the reduction in Australia's credit rating from triple AAA to AA1. The reality is that he has devalued Australia, as he has devalued the Australian dollar.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bananas.

—He is devaluing Australia, as my colleague says, in the banana mode, by affecting people in receipt of superannuation benefits and people on fixed incomes. A succession of taxes have penalised them and put them at a disadvantage. It concerns us that the Government is not only doing this arbitrarily, but also doing it without those people having any opportunity to argue the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's claims to equity in its treatment of wage earners, age pensioners, Commonwealth superannuitants and DFRB-DFRDB pensioners falls apart under close examination. For wage earners, as I have mentioned, the Government will allow a 2 per cent discounting of the 4 per cent CPI movement in the March and June quarters. This has not yet even been argued, much less approved. In any case, one can be sure that it can be expected to operate only from the date of operation of the wages decision. That will probably be some time in December.

I have looked at the case of non-argument. I have looked at the contradiction between what the Minister said and what the Treasurer said. We now get to the time of commencement-10 October, according to this Bill; probably some time in December for the wage earners of Australia. So all of those people who were led to believe that if they tried to care for themselves they would be right are being kicked in the backside by dear old R. J. L. Hawke and his minions. I think it is very sad, because the wage earners will at least receive their full benefit until his commencement date, whatever it might be-some time in December. For aged pensioners, the Government proposes to defer to mid-December the 4 per cent indexation increase due in early November, which is roughly equivalent to a one-off cut of about $26. But Commonwealth superannuitants and the DFRB-DFRDB recipients are hit particularly hard because the discounting will have a cumulative effect. It will not only reduce the benefit now but also reduce the increases they could expect to receive in future years.

They typical DFRB-DFRDB pensioner will see his or her pension reduced by $161.54 in 1986-87 with the cost compounding to $2,031.83 over 10 years, assuming an inflation rate of 5 per cent, and that is probably being a bit ambitious. Effects of a similar nature will apply to all Commonwealth superannuitants. The effect of this measure will cost every recipient of DFRDB and DFRB, as well as Commonwealth superannuitants, about $2,000 over the next 10 years. It is not a light change that is proposed. It is not something that will affect beneficiaries by about $162 this year and only this year. The cost to them over 10 years will be in excess of $2,000.

As a result of the legislation, the Government expects to save $7.9m in public service superannuation this year and $11m in 1987-88. It expects to save a further $4.7m in Service pensions this year and $6.3m more in 1987-88. About 30,000 people receive DFRDB-DFRB benefits, including ex-service personnel and widows. About 1,200 children are beneficiaries. The average pension payment is about $10,000 a year. We should understand that in many ways we are not talking about pensions in the normal sense for servicemen. For most, it is a form of compensation, in the same manner as workers' compensation for those who are injured at work. It is compensation for those who commit themselves and their lives to the hazards of Service life. They are given a DFRDB-DFRB entitlement, and the entitlement of $10,000 a year should be viewed in that light.

This legislation means that the typical married service pensioner will receive an increase of only $230 this year despite having contributed 5.5 per cent of his or her salary for at least 20 years in the belief that there would be a full adjustment of the pension in accordance with the movements of the consumer price index. The Press statement that has been issued on behalf of the Regular Defence Force Welfare Association by Major-General John Whitelaw states:
The Minister assisting the Minister for Defence-
that is the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy)-

in a recent letter said `In DFRDB matters, it is the Parliament which must legislate changes to the Scheme. This is very substantial protection for members because it means that their conditions cannot be changed by a Government in an arbitrary way'.

What the devil is it that the Government is doing if it is not arbitrary? What could be more arbitrary than the Budget changes and the misadjustment that has been made by the man who is Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford)? The changes that he announced in his second reading speech are as arbitrary as anything could be. This is the second time that the Government's 1983 election promise has been broken. It taxed the benefits and now it is reducing them. It is doing so arbitrarily and discriminatorily without anyone in the Services or the Public Service having any opportunity at all to argue his case.

The Government's attacks have sadly created serious problems for the Australian defence forces. Male officer resignations for the first seven months of 1986 were 562, almost as many as the total throughout 1985. Sadly, there is no sign of any improvement. In July and August, the RAAF alone lost 22 skilled pilots, who had been trained at a cost more than $1m each. They are leaving the Services, because the Government is not prepared to provide them with the sort of inducement that they deserve. It is prepared to lop off their superannuation benefit, not to give an inducement to serve and not to take into account the parallel opportunities that are in international and domestic airlines.

Any pilot in the RAAF must have skills that are at least equal to those who fly transport operations, and we all know that those who fly Air Force aircraft go through a significant training period. The skills that they acquire are regarded highly and those skills are not being compensated for in any way, and now they are to be knocked again. Service personnel are leaving the Services, and part of the reason for this happening is the Government's failure to understand that the total measure of pay and conditions that they enjoy is part of the inducement of belonging to the Services. If the Government does not maintain that level of attraction, Service personnel will leave the Services and the Australian Defence Force, whatever the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) might say, will suffer.

One third of the Air Force's losses in the whole of the previous 12 months has been lost in July and August this year. Again, that puts into perspective part of the problem of the increasing number of resignations.

Australian Defence Force losses are unsustainable. As a senior RAAF officer warned in a detailed study this year, unless the losses are stemmed, the RAAF will have to curtail its functions. The FA18 will not be able to be brought into service in the numbers that are now envisaged, and our P3C aircraft are already operating with a serious air crew shortage.

It is clear that at all ranks at all levels in all Services skilled personnel are being lost faster than they are being recruited and trained. This cannot continue. This year, for the first time, Duntroon has not been able to meet all the entries that are required for next year out of its first call for volunteers while maintaining its standards.

That all shows that the Government has not yet got into its noggin that if it wants to get people into the Services it must treat them at least as generously as it does those who are in the civil service. It must take into account the competitive conditions that are enjoyed by those who are in the civilian community. Measures such as the legislation which is before us are adding fuel to an already dangerous wild fire. That is why the Opposition has called repeatedly for a detailed inquiry by the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal into the pay and conditions of the ADF compared with those that apply in the private sector and the Public Service. The Dibb report and the forthcoming White Paper on Defence have received plenty of publicity, but the reality is that unless skilled people are available to operate the highly technical and sophisticated equipment of the ADF, everything will be lost. The Opposition is most concerned that the Bill is yet another cross that the servicemen and servicewomen of Australia will be called upon to bear.

The Armed Forces Federation of Australia's Federal Executive has written to me under the hand of its Federal President, Mr Bob Copley, to express its concern about the Bill. It is concerned especially about a number of aspects of it. It states:

Under the guise of extending the 2 per cent wage discount applying to wages, the Treasurer proposes `discounting' Defence Force Pensions by an equivalent percentage. Unfortunately, this is not what it seems. It is not a notice that a future increase will be discounted. Rather, it involves a decrease in pensions that are being paid now, with effect from October.

That sounds as though the measure is retrospective, but I am assured that while the interest is being paid from July to October, the discounting will apply only to benefits paid from 10 October. I am advised that the measure is not retrospective and that discounting will apply to payments from 10 October, but this is contrary to the arrangements that the Armed Forces Federation of Australia believed would apply, which was the full CPI movement over the next 12 months. I have mentioned the parallel between civilian pensions and wages.
The Federation's second objection is that the Bill effectively takes money

. . . from people's pockets and forces them to arrange their finances accordingly. This contrasts with the situation of `wage discounting' where warning is given and discounting occurs before an indexation increase is paid. In this case the reduction is real and its effect will compound in the future.
The effect will compound, and the cost will be more than $2,000 for many service beneficiaries in the future. In that circumstance, the Federation's concern is fully justified.
The Federation's letter continues:

The proposal would again differ from `wage discounting' in that it denies any semblance of `natural justice'. Unlike `wage discounting' the proposed DFRDB discount has not been contested on its merits before any industrial tribunal. Consequently, neither recipients nor their representatives have had the opportunity to present any mitigating case.
The Opposition is concerned about that and I have tried to set down the circumstances where that applies. The Federation has asked for three specific guarantees, which are as follows:
1. Ensure any future alterations are made through legislation separate to the DFRDB Act, including a `sunset clause' limiting its lifetime-as occurred with the Salaries and Wages Pause Act.
That is not specifically applicable to the Bill because the Opposition understands that a once-off discounting is proposed. Accordingly, a `sunset clause' is not applicable.
Secondly, the Federation has asked that the Government:
Ensure reductions, if any, are determined only by the outcome of the next National Wage Case.
We believe that that is highly desirable and would have been a far preferable course for the Government to take. Thirdly, the Federation asks that the Government:
Guarantee that the power to alter pension rates continues to rest solely with the Parliament and is not delegated as an administrative function.

To that we say: `Hear, hear!' The Opposition treats the provisions in the Bill as being part of the Government's Budget. It is concerned about overall public sector spending and it does not like the package. It does not like the Government's presentation. However, we do not believe that it is appropriate for us in this climate to oppose the Bill, although in government we would be acting in an entirely different way. We regret that the Government has introduced the measure in such a way that if we vote against it we shall affect the amount to be spent this year. It is only on the basis that there would, therefore, be an increase in government spending, at a time when it has not cut government spending enough, that we find ourselves in the predicament of opposing the context of what it does but not being able to vote against it. In that climate, therefore, I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House-

(1) expresses its concern that the level of discounting of superannuation, Defence Forces Retirement Benefits (DFRB) and Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits (DFRDB) pensions imposed by the legislation has not yet been proposed in a National Wage Case, let alone given effect by a decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and notes that: (a) the Bill imposes on Commonwealth superannuitants, without consultation, a burden greater than that proposed for the community generally, in that it will come into effect before equivalent discounting of wages is even considered; (b) discounting of DFRB and DFRDB pensions further erodes conditions of service in the Australian Defence Force (ADF) at a time when ADF resignations are at near-crisis level, and (c) the Bill breaks, for the second time, Labor's 1983 election promise not to cut DFRB and DFRDB benefits, and

(2) further calls on the Government to direct the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal, as a matter of urgency, to inquire into the adequacy of pay and conditions of service in the ADF compared with those in the private sector and public service'.
We believe that the Bill is not appropriate and we urge all honourable members of the House to support that in-principle opposition, for in government we would act in a totally different fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Bill 1986, and to oppose the amendment moved by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair). The legislation before us today is more concrete proof of the Hawke Government's determination to make the hard economic decisions which are necessary to see us through our current difficulties and its commitment to see that the burdens of the next 12 months are shouldered fairly throughout the community. Through legislation such as this Bill, the Government is putting into practice the restraint which Australians have universally acknowledged is necessary at present.

SPEECH.PARA: Amid the complaints and objections of the Opposition, it is necessary to keep in mind why we need such changes as this legislation, and to retain our perspective of which members of the community are being asked to make sacrifices. The bottom line reality, which even the Opposition by now must understand, is our adverse balance of trade. It is not the fault of the Government, the unions or business that the products which we sell overseas have undergone a staggering loss in value over recent times. This year alone has seen $6 billion slashed from our export earnings. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said in his Budget Speech, we cannot sustain such price falls and carry on as if nothing has happened. The reaction of this Government has been sane, just and responsible-in short, the very opposite of what the Opposition's has been. Admittedly, we do not know too much about exactly what the Opposition would have done, but we can be fairly sure that the present Government's welfare cut of $500m would look fairly paltry compared to what our opponents would have done.

The keynote to Labor's restraint, whether in welfare or wages, has been the discounting of future consumer price index increases, rather than the more draconian outright cuts which those on the other side of the House would prefer. Whilst we recognise the need to adjust our standards in line with our changed trading circumstances, the Government's philosophy is to do this over time through granting less than full flow-ons. This method gives people more leeway to cope with the changes ahead. Thus pensioners and social security clients will have their normal November six-monthly adjustment delayed until mid-December. Even this practice is minimal when compared to that asked of wage earners, who will have their next CPI rise of 4 per cent cut back to 2 per cent. Indeed the workers of this country, for all the recent talk in the Press about bullying trade unions, have shown remarkable responsibility over the life of the prices and incomes accord in holding back wage rises. In fact, we have seen in this country a fall in real wages over the last three years of 5 per cent at a time when real wages of some of our major trading partners, including Japan, have been rising.

In this climate of restraint and responsibility each section of the community has been asked to make sacrifices. I am proud to be able to say that most Australians have accepted the challenge. There are a handful of whingers who are still complaining about the loss of the fringe benefits rort, but by and large the community has responded positively. The Bill before us asks for that same commitment, albeit to a lesser degree, from two other groups in the community-Commonwealth superannuitants, and Defence Force retirees under the relevant Acts. Effectively, those who draw a pension or superannuation payment under the five Acts concerned are being asked to forgo 2 per cent of their nominal increase under the CPI flow-on. This increase is made every year in July, the increase being based upon the CPI increase in the six capital cities from March to March. In the current year a rise of 9.2 per cent was granted. The present Bill reduces the flow-on from 9.2 per cent to 7.2 per cent from 10 October this year, so that the new pension will be modified as if the increase given in July had been 7.2 per cent.

The groups to be affected by the move fall into two major categories: Firstly, those under the Commonwealth Superannuation Acts 1922 and 1976; secondly, those Defence Force personnel who receive pensions under the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Act 1948 and the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973. A third and far smaller category are affected under the Papua New Guinea (Staffing Assistance) (Superannuation) Regulations.

The sacrifice being asked of superannuation recipients is certainly no greater than that which the bulk of the work force is already making, and it is also a decrease which in total will reduce outlays considerably. Under the superannuation Acts alone, $7.9m is expected to be saved in 1986-7, while $11m will be saved in the following financial year. The savings under the Defence Force funds will be $4.7m this financial year and $6.3m in the next. The new arrangements will affect more than 112,000 beneficiaries under the present Act, including the spouses and children of former beneficiaries. The crux of the legislation deals with a future reduction of the 9.2 per cent annual CPI increase by 2 per cent, so that persons retiring after the CPI rise was granted have already had their payments accounted for as part of their salary entitlement on retirement. The reduction will take place in this way: From 10 October pensions will be readjusted as if the 9.2 per cent increase granted in July had been only 7.2 per cent for the year. The pension will then be changed to give that outcome for the year. Thus a pension of $10,452, which was the average pension paid for the year ended 30 June 1985, when adjusted for a 9.2 per cent rise in July would normally expect to attract a $962 increase over the year. The increase now will be $753 for the year or a loss of $4 per week. No money will be reclaimed, but, rather, the increase will be reduced to create the same outcome for the entire year. The decreases are thus not retrospective but account for a full year's adjustment.

I now turn to the recipients under the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. This move has been billed as harsh and discriminatory against those in the public sector; but that is not so, because the annual method of making indexation increases has put retirees in a better position than that of their colleagues still at work. In 1961, 1963, 1967 and 1971 the government-financed portion of pensions was increased by the `notional salary' method, whereby pensions were upgraded in line with updated levels of a pensioner's retirement salary. From 1973, however, a new system of annual increase was introduced. From 1976 the annual increase has been updated in line with the consumer price index. As is well known, the overall wage outcomes under the accord have been below full CPI increases, and the area of white collar workers is no different. Between 30 June 1976 and 30 June 1986 Commonwealth superannuation scheme pensions operating under the 1922 Act increased by 171 per cent. Those under the 1976 Act have increased by 139 per cent. By comparison, the salary for a clerk class 2/3 public servant has increased by only 117 per cent. The discounting now called for will reduce the increase for 1922 Act pensions to 165 per cent while 1976 Act pensions will be down to 135 per cent. These figures are still in excess of the salary increase of people still working. It would be the height of unfairness for this Government to expect one group to shoulder the full burden while letting another portion of the community go scot free. It can be seen as especially inequitable when it is noted that superannuitants have already outstripped workers' pay rises by so much.

I would now like to deal with defence forces retirees who will be affected by the present Act. There has been a good deal of controversy about the proposed changes to defence pensions, most recently in yesterday's Australian. The complaint made is that former members of the defence forces are being asked to make greater sacrifices than pensioners in general. According to one report, their decrease will be six times greater than that of the average age pensioner. I do not wish to enter into the arithmetic of that claim but I would question the validity of the comparison. Those employing the argument are playing on public ignorance of the facts and are assuming that a Defence Force retiree is in the same position as an age pensioner, yet that is not the case at all.

If we look at last year's Defence Force retirees who claim pensions under the two relevant Acts, we see that 2,230 men and women took up the pension. Of these, 79 per cent were 45 years old or younger and 56 per cent were 40 years old or younger. It is quite common practice for service personnel upon retiring to commence a new career in another sphere of life altogether. In such circumstances the Defence Force retirement benefit becomes a rather useful second income. Even if the person under consideration is retired, the probability is that he or she has invested in some further retirement benefit in the course of his or her second career, in which case the Defence Force benefit is again a comfortable addition. The comparison between the average age pensioner and the average Defence Force pensioner is therefore just not on. Either those who make the comparison are unaware of the facts or, worse, they are deliberately trying to mislead the public into believing that an injustice has been done. I call on them to come clean with the full story.

Even if we consider the case of that very small group of persons who rely on the Defence Force pension for their entire income in retirement, we must take into account the fact that such a person can also claim a proportion of the age pension. In the case of a married couple on the average Defence Force benefit, which from 10 October this year will be $9,934 per annum, the addition of the age pension proportion will make them approximately $121 a week better off than the equivalent age pensioner couple.

When we consider the delay in the introduction of legislation against poverty traps we can see that in comparison with age pensioners Defence Force retirees have done very well. Those who persist in drawing out this facile comparison are doing no more than playing to the gallery, engaging in a cynical show for their own electoral benefit. No one likes to have to make cuts, even in the national interest. Even less pleasant is to be on the receiving end of those cuts. By forcing unreasonable comparisons, the Opposition is attempting to make injustice out of an exercise which is manifestly equitable.

The Opposition's argument is a double deceit. On the one hand it creates the impression that the superannuitants concerned should not be touched by the present decreases, thus leaving more burden to be shouldered by the rest of the community. On the other hand, we know that any Opposition Budget would leave out the really needy far more than our Budget did. We know that the $500m cut in welfare outlays was not enough for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). We know too that the Opposition would abandon altogether the next national wage rise and put working men and women on a wage freeze for at least a year while prices rose unhindered around them. For the Opposition to claim now that defence pensions are sacrosanct is the height of hypocrisy.

I say in conclusion that this Bill is another dose of that hard medicine about which we have heard so much. Like our initiatives towards restraint, it blends equity with responsibility, ensuring that no section of the community has to take on a burden too great for it. No section of the community is unfairly or harshly dealt with by these changes, and I am certain that those affected by this Bill will accept the changes in the general understanding of a need for restraint.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Bill. It provides that pensions payable to, or in relation to, former Commonwealth Government employees and Defence Force personnel shall be effectively discounted by 2 per cent. The extraordinary circumstances of the economy over the last two years have required the Government to take a number of tough decisions, but more importantly, it has necessitated all members of the community accepting and sharing the cost of reduced government expenditure. That is primarily what this legislation is all about. Accordingly, as it was announced in the Budget last month, the 2 per cent wage discounting which was recently applied to wages, is to be extended to government superannuation benefits which are payable to, or in relation to, former Commonwealth Government employees and Defence Force personnel.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some cost saving measures which necessarily flow from this piece of legislation, and they are not insignificant. Indeed, over the course of 1986-87, which is not the full year, savings will amount to almost $13m for the Commonwealth, and during the course of the full year 1987-88 it is expected to result in savings to the Commonwealth of some $17.3m. This is by no means an insignificant piece of legislation and in terms of the Government's overall Budget strategy, which required zero real growth in outlays and a Budget deficit of $3.5 billion, this Bill forms a crucial part of that overall strategy.

I make reference to some of those extraordinary economic circumstances which, as I have said, necessitated the Budget strategy by this Government-the zero real growth in outlays-and which has resulted in probably the second or third toughest Budget that Australia has experienced since the Second World War. That is why this legislation is necessary. I will just point to a few of those indicators. I think it is fairly well known throughout Australia that as a result of the downturn in export prices that Australia receives, our export income has been reduced by some billions of dollars and our standard of living has been effectively reduced by 2 per cent to 3 per cent. As a responsible government wanting to plan ahead for the future to give this economy the chance to adjust to those changed economic circumstances, we have brought down a Budget which gives effect to those economic conditions.

I will give a few examples of what has happened to the price we receive for our traditional exports. Between 1981 and 1985 average coal export prices fell by around 28 per cent. Between 1980 and 1985 wheat prices fell by 27 per cent. Over the same five year period the price of wool fell by 22 per cent. In the last five years the price of iron ore fell by 26 per cent. The price of aluminium is down 26 per cent. The price of beef is down 24 per cent and the price of sugar is down 68 per cent. I could go on and on with that list. Basically what has occurred over this period, but particularly during the last year, is that the world is no longer prepared to pay us the price for the commodities and goods which we have traditionally exported. That has meant that our export income is much lower than it otherwise would be. It has meant that we are down the drain about $6 billion a year because those prices did not remain at a reasonable level and that means that our standard of living has fallen. When we came to frame the Budget--

We would argue very strongly that if it is fair for wage and salary earners to take a 2 per cent discount previously, and most likely a 2 per cent discount again in the future, it is only reasonable that beneficiaries of superannuation who have been Commonwealth employees should also share in the burden that the rest of the community is sharing in and accept a 2 per cent discount.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view it would be absurd, indeed, extremely ironic, if someone remaining in the work force-for instance, a member of the Defence Force-in his or her occupation was to take a 2 per cent wage discount, yet a colleague who had recently retired on a pension and who was not working was getting a greater increase in their pension per week than the person remaining in work. I think that would be an absurd and a totally contradictory situation. This legislation has been introduced to ensure for that very good reason that that does not occur.

The issue has been raised today as to why it is that a higher effective discount is being applied to the public sector. I just make these points: Over the years Commonwealth superannuation pensioners have benefited from indexation increases which have been generally in excess of salary movements in that sector. For instance, in 1961, 1963, 1967, and 1971 the Government financed portion of pensions was increased by the notional salary method, which provided for pension increases to be determined having regard to the updated level of a pensioner's retirement salary. When regular annual adjustments were introduced in 1973, pensions were increased by applying to the Government financed portion the formula of whichever was the lesser of 1.4 times the movement in the consumer price index or one times the movement in average weekly earnings.

Since 1976 these pensions have been fully updated by one times the movement in the consumer price index. The Government financed portion of these pensions that have become payable since 1 July 1976 under the Superannuation Act of 1976 have been fully updated by movements in the CPI. Movements in the CPI, in fact, have been well in excess of increments in the level of public sector salaries. Between June 1976 and July 1986 pensions under the Superannuation Act 1922 increased by 171 per cent. It is an important statistic. Pensions under the Superannuation Act increased by 139 per cent. But by comparison-it is a very important comparison to make-the salary for a class 2/3 clerk in the Public Service in that time has increased by only 117 per cent. In other words, over the period in question in the last decade, the increases paid to Commonwealth superannuation beneficiaries have been well in excess of the salary increases paid to people who are in ordinary Public Service employment.

The effect of this piece of legislation is that discounting will reduce the level of increase to 165 per cent in respect of pensions covered by the 1922 Act and to 135 per cent in respect of pensions covered by the 1976 Act. I understand that all of that sounds fairly technical but in simple terms it means that Commonwealth superannuation pensioners in fact have done very well from the indexation of pensions over the last decade. They have done far better than their counterparts who have remained in regular Public Service employment. When we come to 1986-87, where in the last year we have had a dramatic fall in our national income and a dramatic fall in our export income, and where wage and salary earners have been forced to take a 2 per cent reduction in wages, in all conscience how could a responsible government say that those who have retired from the Commonwealth Public Service should get full consumer price indexation of pensions whereas those remaining in work should only get the 7.2 per cent-2 per cent less. In all conscience one cannot do that. If a government takes a responsible position about this, if it is prepared to and knows that it has to make the tough right decisions in terms of Australia's long term future, this legislation is the only possible result that one can get from that scenario. For those reasons I strongly support the legislation.

This legislation provides for superannuation and other benefits, so its embrace is fairly wide. The approach which has been adopted by this Government is a reasoned, gradual approach. It produces the necessary adjustments in our economy in a reasoned way over time. It is totally different from the approach which, presumably, would be adopted by a Liberal-National Party coalition if it were ever returned to government. The Opposition has suggested that it will oppose sections of this legislation. I have great difficulty coming to terms with its opposition to this legislation. If one looks at the Opposition's record in terms of benefits payable to people in our community, one sees that it is a deplorable record of slashing the living standards of people who depend on pensions and benefits.

For instance, during the Fraser Government, of which the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was the Treasurer, the additional pension for children fell by 35 per cent in real terms. The allowance for guardians fell by 34.7 per cent. The single adult unemployment benefit fell in real terms by 18.6 per cent, and the junior unemployment benefit fell by 45.6 per cent. When we talk about a 2 per cent discount to superannuation beneficiaries, bearing in mind that wage earners have already taken a 2 per cent discount, we have to take the opposition by the Liberal and National parties to this legislation with a grain of salt. We should look a little further at what they might do in the future. I am sure that all honourable members would recall the middle of last year when the President of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr John Valder, advocated in his widely circulated video, the so-called Westpac video, huge cuts in social security benefits. Brown), has been particularly vocal. He said that the Opposition would simply abolish benefits for the long term unemployed if it got into power. That is a remarkable assertion. Even with the dramatic job growth that has occurred under this Government, there are still about 15 applicants for every job vacancy. So I do not know what a long term unemployment beneficiary would do--
