He pointed out very effectively this afternoon the dire consequences of this kind of reduction in recognition of service to the country, whether it be in the Public Service or in the defence forces.

What has been lost sight of, undoubtedly, is that by reducing the benefits we merely push many of these people further into the area of social welfare. This, I believe, is a tragic approach by any government that wants to encourage people to have greater reliance on their own resources in their retirement. If there is to be a trend in this direction, let us think of the consequences. It means that people will say: `Is it worth while to contribute to a superannuation fund? Is it worth while to try to provide for one's retirement?'. The answer, obviously, is that, if this is to be the Government's policy in future and if this is a lead towards its attitudes, it is contrary even to trade union policy. I do not know what the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), who represents the Minister for Finance and who is at the table, will tell us about that. But on the one hand we have a very great demand from the trade union movement for an expansion of superannuation, for an all-embracing system of superannuation in this country, and, on the other, in this case we are reducing a genuine, proper and sensibly based superannuation provision.

I am amazed that the honourable member for Bendigo this afternoon could cite percentage bases when making comparisons about existing benefits. In other words, he put to this House that, even with the cut in superannuation benefit, there were still people on full salaries who, in percentage terms, were receiving less. What utter humbug! What rubbish! It is rubbish because one cannot refer to percentages when one makes that comparison. Of course, on a percentage basis, there would be people receiving lower salaries. Is that any surprise?

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't ask me. I didn't make the speech.

—The honourable member is the only Government back bencher in the House at the moment who can back up his colleague. There are two Ministers at the table. I do not know whether we will hear from them, but I hope that we will hear from one of them.

—Obviously, the honourable member for Bendigo is an academic. At least, he expresses, on behalf of his back bench colleagues, an academic attitude on all matters on which he speaks. SPEECH.PARA: We know that the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, in his second reading speech, indicated to us that this measure was being implemented on the premise that because the automatic increases in superannuation were based on certain weighted averages-on the average consumer price index for the six capital cities-it was pretty generous. But let us look at the real facts. We are talking about an increase, that would have applied, in an average superannuation situation, of about $962 a year. This proposal cuts that amount back to $753 a year, which represents $4 a week. If one relates that to present day living costs-and that is the issue-$4 a week is a very substantial erosion of benefit for those people who are receiving a superannuation benefit. I draw the attention of the House to what this Government has done to superannuation generally since it came to office, despite its promises in 1983. TALK.START.PARA: —In closing the debate on the second reading, I want to thank all the members who have taken part. Some, of course, made more worthwhile contributions than others. SPEECH.PARA: The House-

(1) expresses its concern that the level of discounting of superannuation . . . imposed by the legislation has not yet been proposed in a National Wage Case, let alone given effect by a decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), who I understand led for the Opposition-I apologise that I was not able to be here at the time-apparently made some reference to page 10 of the Budget Speech and quoted the part that states:
. . . the Government will argue to the Arbitration Commission that the proposed increase in wages be cut by 2 per cent.

As I said in my second reading speech, on 26 June, in the national wage case decision brought down on that day, a 2.3 per cent increase was granted in relation to the September and December 1985 consumer price index increase of 4.3 per cent. The 2.3 per cent increase applied from the first pay in July 1986. The difference between the 4.3 per cent which would otherwise have applied and the 2.3 per cent that applied was the 2 per cent, which is the rationale for what is taking place now.

The amendment is, of course, nonsense. It is built on a misconception. Superannuation fund pensioners received automatically a 9.2 per cent increase based on indexation on 3 July 1986 in respect of the April 1985 and March 1986 increases in the CPI. To introduce equity, the Bill is applying a 2 per cent discount.
I draw attention to another part of the Opposition's misconceived amendment, which reads:
(a) the Bill imposes on Commonwealth superannuitants, without consultation, a burden greater than that proposed for the community generally.
It does not. As I have explained, the community generally has already had the 2 per cent discount to indexation applied to general wages. There is no inequity in what is being proposed.

The honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) made a comment to which I want to refer. Members' contributions do not subsidise, so to speak, the annual indexation of pension payments. Members who retire without a pension entitlement, for example, receive a refund of their 5.5 per cent contributions. The cost of indexed pension increases is borne by the government of the day, and this Government has not abrogated its responsibilities under the various Acts that provide for an annual increase in Defence Force retirement pensions, but in the current economic climate the rate of pension increase cannot be sustained. For the sake of equity, too, it has been necessary to apply the 2 per cent discount.

Most Australians understand the concept of equity, and that applies to those who have retired. These are people who have given their services in the Defence Force and elsewhere and who are beneficiaries of the fund. They will not be making the sort of fuss that the Opposition is making. As I have said, the amendment is a nonsense. The same can be said of the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson), who seemed to see some need to suggest that the Bill is in conflict with the Government's desire to extend superannuation. The Government has a keen desire to ensure that superannuation is extended to lower income group people in the community who presently do not have this benefit.

Even though the times are difficult ones economically, with a reduction in the prices of our exports being imposed from outside the country-these problems are not in any way due to government policy-we are not putting aside our objectives. We wish to ensure that proper retirement benefits go to those who deserve them. The Bill is not in conflict with the Government's desire to extend superannuation. It is a measure which is bringing equity in benefits in line with the 2 per cent discount in respect of wages that has applied to the rest of the community. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN LAND TRANSPORT (FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before us is the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1986. Its purpose is to reduce the amount of Federal road finance for 1986-87 by $50m to $1,245m. This will be achieved by reducing the hypothecated excise on petrol and diesel fuel by 0.235c per litre, which in turn will reduce the amount to be retained in the Australian Land Transport Program Trust Fund and thus to be available for expenditure on the nation's roads. The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) revealed this bad news in June, but the road construction industry, State and local governments, automobile associations and others can be forgiven for being confused, because since then there has been a further reduction, in the Budget, of $24m. The result for 1986-87-and I presume we can accept that there will be no further reductions-is the dismal figure of $1,245m allocated for the nation's roads, which is the same level in current or nominal terms for the third year in succession. It brings with it an equally dismal record for this Government, because for only the second time in the 11 years during which the Australian Automobile Association chart has provided figures on this, and for which I will seek incorporation in Hansard later, there has been no increase in nominal or current dollar terms for Federal road expenditure. Both of those years were during the term of this Australian Labor Party Government-that is, last year and this year.

SPEECH.PARA: To understand fully both what this $74m reduction in Federal road finance means to the level of road construction and maintenance and what it does to the incorrect but nevertheless persistent bombast of the Government in relation to its priorities for road expenditure, I shall quote from the Minister's second reading speech on the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Bill 1985. I want to highlight some of the arrogance-which I think must now be obvious to everyone and which we tried to show last year-of the Government. The Minister said:

The Bill now before the House will be the foundation upon which our overall approach to transport will be based. It provides a use related basis for determining Federal expenditure on land transport systems. Furthermore the arrangements incorporate an automatic adjustment to match future inflationary movements as measured by the consumer price index.

It guarantees the continuity of the greatest road building program in Australia's history, which has been progressively implemented during our two years of government. Together with the Australian Bicentennial Road Development-ABRD-program, federal expenditure on roads will total $1,245m in 1985-86.
Later he stated:

The Bill establishes a trust fund, which will operate on a similar basis to the ABRD Trust Fund. It provides that an indexed share of the existing excise charge on motor spirit and diesel fuel will be paid into the ALTP Trust Fund based on collections from 1 July 1985 until 30 June 1990.
He further stated:
The future level of expenditure under ALTP will depend upon the following two factors:
-The rate of consumption of motor spirit and diesel which is the best measure of road use-and the rate of movements in the Consumer Price Index to maintain the ALTP excise component in real terms.

Specifically in this Bill we have the fulfilment of this Government's long standing policy commitment to the improvement of our nation's road system-a system which under conservative governments was starved of essential investment funds.

What an arrogance that is when we see what is actually being spent by this Government on the nation's roads. What is the real position with this Government's level of expenditure? There are two ways of determining whether the Federal Government is giving adequate priority to road expenditure. The first is based on excise, that is, the percentage of fuel excise or, for that matter, total Federal fuel taxes-both the excise and the levy-allocated to roads. I believe that this comparison is unreliable because there are, as we are now finding almost daily, considerable variations depending on the import parity price which, in turn, alters the crude oil levy and the excise relationship. Also, it is does not recognise the legitimate right of a Federal government to tax fuel to an acceptable degree as part of that government's income requirement. However, I agree with those who criticise the excessive level of taxation, which amounts to about 9 per cent of total Commonwealth income, when in this current year only about 16 1/2 per cent of that amount will be spent on our roads. Let us compare that figure with the high point of over 21 per cent in 1983-84, the first full year of the initiation of the Australian bicentennial road development program by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) on behalf of the coalition Government.

The Australian Automobile Association uses the second form of comparison, that is, the percentage of total government expenditure allocated to roads. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table supplied by the Australian Automobile Association.

TALK.START.PARA: —The three important columns in that 11-year table indicate, first of all, total funding or total Federal expenditure on roads; secondly, the total Budget outlays or expenditure; and, thirdly,-the right hand column-the percentage of total Federal government expenditure which is actually allocated to roads. For example, in 1976-77 the percentage of total Commonwealth funding was 1.80 per cent, and the level was the same in 1979-80. The low point was in 1981-82, when the percentage was 1.66 per cent. Funding then climbed rapidly with the introduction of the bicentennial road development program. It reached its peak of 2.12 per cent in 1983-84, the first full impact year of the 2c per litre levy. I remind everyone present that the ABRD program was introduced in 1982 by the honourable member for Gwydir on behalf of the coalition Government. In 1982-83 the levy was 1c per litre and in 1983-84 it was 2c per litre. I also remind everyone that the levy was opposed by the Australian Labor Party at that time. However, since then, in government, the Labor Party has been very quick in its Press statements and speeches to claim the credit for the beneficial effects of the ABRD program on our road finances.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government has not just been content with accepting the credit for the ABRD program which it initially opposed; it indexed that 2c per litre levy and has paid all of that indexed portion into Consolidated Revenue. Over the five-year period of the bicentennial road program, over $500m of what should be money for Australia's roads is disappearing completely into Consolidated Revenue. The Government and the Minister love to boast how they have given such a high priority to road finance in their Budgets. To make that point, I refer to the Minister's second reading speech. The Government always cites the figure for 1981-82, the last full year of the coalition Government. The Australian Automobile Association table confirms that low point.

Let us look at the situation over five Labor Budgets. For a start the figure given for funding in 1981-82 is always wrong because the figure for the last coalition Budget-1982-83-is far higher. Labor has falsely claimed the credit for the 1982-83 funding level. The first full year of the 2c per litre levy, the high point of Federal road finance, was 1983-84. Once again it flowed automatically from the coalition Government initiative. In 1984-85 there was a funding reduction in real terms of several per cent. In 1985-86 the $1,245m funding level, the figure for the previous year, was retained. Therefore the reduction in real terms is the full extent of inflation for that year. In 1986-87, the current year, the funding level of $1,245m has been retained, once again bearing the full reduction of inflation for the year. The three Budgets that have on them the imprint of Labor-1984-85, 1985-86 and 1986-87-indicate a fall of about 20 per cent in real terms in finance allocated by this Government for road expenditure and maintenance around Australia. That is the real story of what this Government is doing for road finance in this country.

The Minister and the Government have been fond of citing in all their Press releases an 82 per cent funding increase in nominal terms since 1981-82. I know that the Government can still use the 1981-82 figure because the Automobile Association table indicates that 1.67 per cent of total government expenditure in 1986-87, compared with 1.66 per cent in 1981-82, will be allocated to roads. However, I caution it against that because the Federal Budget deficit will certainly blow out far beyond the guesstimate of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of a little over $3.5 million. Put another way, expenditure for this financial year will be far greater than $74,764 million, and that is the figure on which the Automobile Association table is based. We have only to remember 1985-86 when final Government expenditure was over $800m more than the original guesstimate. The Government has to increase its expenditure by only $236m to $75 billion to reduce that percentage to the same as it was in 1981-82. To get the figure down to 1.65 per cent, which would be the lowest level of Federal expenditure in the 11 years covered by the Automobile Association table, total expenditure has to increase by only an additional $690m. I again remind honourable members that the deficit blow-out last year was over $800m.

Even looking at those figures is being kind to this Government because the calculations do not include ALTP finance, which can be diverted from road expenditure at the request of the States to interstate mainline rail upgrading, and I would be interested to hear from the Minister what is happening in that respect. There is also the uncertainty of further amendments being introduced in the mini-Budget next year, and for that matter, next year's Budget. There is the uncertainty of what to expect in real money terms for road finance in the years ahead. That does not even include one other aspect of uncertainty: The phoney accounting of a $24m reduction in this year's Budget. That $24m is additional to the $50m which we are specifically referring to and is money that is being collected this year from the motorists. It is collected as excise and paid into the ALTP trust fund. It is not being allocated for the much needed expenditure on our roads; it is being kept in the trust fund to artificially reduce the deficit.

I return to the earlier point of fuel taxation versus government revenue versus road finance. The Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into Certain Petroleum Products, which is still in progress, is of considerable interest. The second draft report was released in August. It was released ahead of the Budget. But that second draft report is dramatically different to the first draft report which was released earlier in the year. The second report recognises the deliberate Government policy of breaking the import parity price policy by taxing the difference. In other words, instead of the motorists benefiting from the reduced world price of crude oil the Government pocketed the difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did it give it back when the price went back up?

—It did not. In fact, it made it worse. The House will recall that in the Budget it increased the levy by a further 3c a litre. It just compounded the problem. The IAC is highlighting, to those who read these reports, that this Government is now using fuel as the most direct source of revenue that any government ever has to overcome its budgetary deficit problems. The IAC concluded that the excise on petrol and diesel is too high, and that it is unfair in its impact. I certainly agree with both those points. One has to consider how country people need to rely on fuel for the greater distances, for freight, et cetera. All road users-indeed anyone who is in an export industry-have the added burden of the relatively high price of fuel for use on farms and in other industries in relation to many of our competitors. The IAC in its draft summary recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: As discussed in chapter 6, and as suggested by a number of participants at the first draft report hearing, a broadening of the commodity tax base by introduction of a Broad Based Consumption Tax (BBCT) or a Value Added Tax (VAT) would be expected to have a number of benefits. In particular, as discussed in the Draft White Paper on reform of Australia's tax system, such taxes would have the ability to relieve the burden on the income tax system. In addition they would provide scope to reduce petroleum excises. The Draft White Paper proposed a BBCT at a rate of 12 1/2 per cent. A further $2 billion would be raised by increasing this rate to 15 per cent. This would be sufficient to allow the excise rate on petrol, diesel and aviation fuel to fall to a level more comparable to other products in the economy.

We must seriously consider that IAC recommendation. I would be very surprised if in its final report it moved in any substantial way from its recommendation of the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax in which fuel is taxed at the same rate as other products and services and not at the punitive rate which it has become in this country, and that specific road user charges be levied, but that all the income derived from those specific road user charges-there are a number of ways in which such charges could be made-would be allocated for the construction and maintenance of this nation's roads. The total cost of the tax and the specific road user charge would be less than current fuel taxes.

In addition to the Labor Government's failure to maintain Federal road finance in real terms and the prospect of a continuing and accelerating decline between now and the next election and the end of the ABRD program in 1988, we pose a serious question: What happens after 1988 when the ABRD program and its 2c a litre levy ends? The ABRD now constitutes over one-third of Federal road finance. It is imperative that Federal road expenditure be maintained either by an extension of the ABRD program or by a combined ALTP and ABRD program which in total will maintain the level of road finance for the nation's roads and, what is more, guarantee that that level be maintained, unlike the very uncertain situation this Government has created.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certain in one way-that the road funds will be decreased over the years.

—The honourable member for Gippsland makes a very relevant and important point on behalf of the rural electorate, that fuel taxes, in total, must be lowered over a number of years but that expenditure must be maintained. At present, the coalition is studying the best way to achieve this end. I make this point for the Minister: The coalition parties are once again committed to the continuation of specific road grants for Federal road finance. The Opposition's concern over the Government's failure to maintain the nation's roads has caused the Opposition to consider an amendment. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not opposing the passage of this Bill, the House condemns the Government for its disgraceful neglect of the nation's roads by-

(1) being responsible for a dramatic fall in Federal expenditure in real terms since 1983-84 from 2.12 per cent of total budget outlays to 1.95 per cent in 1984-85, and 1.78 per cent in 1985-86 and an estimated 1.67 per cent this financial year, as measured by the Australian Automobile Association;
(2) retaining Federal expenditure on roads at the same nominal level at $1,245m for the third year in succession;

(4) reducing the allocation to roads while at the same time increasing fuel excise tax by over 300 per cent in 3 years of Government;

SPEECH.PARA: It is also time that the Opposition parties really decided what they wanted. It is no good them running around the country calling for cuts. `Cuts, cuts, cuts' they are saying. I am sure that all honourable members, like me, felt a sense of pride at seeing the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) on television when the last link in the north of Western Australia was sealed a few weeks back. This had been one of the major national highway objectives-another magnificent objective achieved by this Government. Other objectives being met are upgradings to meet the growing needs for safe and efficient road transport between major centres of population. The Government stands by its fundamental objectives and it is committed to improving one of Australia's greatest national assets, our national highway system. Despite all the money spent on this section, and bearing in mind that not one penny was spent by the previous Government on this section even though it was represented by a Liberal Party of Australia member, the Liberal-National Party members, including the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), who should know better, and the two local State members-the honourable member for Goulburn and the honourable member for Camden-keep peddling the story that money has been diverted from this section to the Newcastle area. In addition to the increase in specific purpose road funding, general purpose financial assistance for local government is to be maintained in real terms over the next two years. A major proportion of Federal road funds-75 per cent-is spent in non-metropolitan areas, maintaining employment and substantiating economic activity in rural areas. It is estimated, for example, that for every $1m spent on better roads, 60 jobs or thereabouts are created. These jobs are vital, especially in country areas. So much for the humbug and hypocrisy of National Party members, such as the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), who last week, in this chamber, called for a zero deficit. The promise of new domestic and international terminals at Darwin Airport has been deferred, which is too polite a euphemism for it. Alice Springs Airport, one of the busiest airports in Australia, has been left in the lurch whilst, in a politically discriminatory way, funds have gone to a much quieter airport than either Alice Springs or Darwin airports-to Townsville Airport. There are exactly 32 units of tourist accommodation available in Kakadu National Park, because that is all this Government has permitted to be constructed, despite numerous groups wanting to put tourist facilities into the park.

When Northern Territorians talk of railing against this Government, it is more than just a deliberate pun. When this Government is thrown out of office at the next election, it will be a matter of great celebration in my distant and remote electorate, the Northern Territory, which, the Minister may care to recall, is still a special responsibility of the Commonwealth. I had cause to mention the accelerated Stuart Highway program in speaking on the 1985-86 Budget. I said then that the program could more aptly be named the `dust to dust and ashes to ashes program'.

Let us look at the historical facts on Australian land transport, particularly as they affect the road program between northern and southern Australia. In 1982, the Australian bicentennial roads program was introduced, with its special emphasis being on the national highway system, and its timing to take us to the end of 1988. The notional allocation to the Northern Territory under that program was determined at $11.1m. In addition, this year the Territory should have received another $4.4m. This extra money was in direct compensation for the totally unnecessary and deliberately punitive freeze imposed upon the Territory's road program by this Minister in 1983-84-the justification being that everything was on hold while the Darwin-Alice Springs railway was under consideration. `Under consideration' was a nice euphemism. The railway was about as much `under consideration' as is a chicken on the chopping block.

In 1985-86, instead of the expected $15m for roads, being the total of Australian bicentennial road program sharing and the shortfall from the 1983-84 freeze, the Territory received just $10.6 million. That means that the Territory suffered just short of a one-third cut in road program funding in the 1985-86 year. On top of this, the ASH program was totally abandoned. Demon strably, money is not being spent `bringing Australians closer together'.

For the sake of all Australia, I hope that the Government succeeds in reducing the deficit since it must, most certainly, be undertaken as a matter of great urgency. I ask the Minister to drop the rhetoric about bringing Australians closer together while he is demonstrably doing everything to put distance between them.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill and the essential elements of road funding which it embraces represent a set of issues which are at once related both to the security and vitality of our economy and the health and safety of those Australians who participate in it.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of road funding which this Bill addresses is linked inseparably to road safety and the causal relationship between the construction of a safe and effective road system and the greater safety of Australian road users, a truism which no observer could fail to recognise. For the same reason, no informed observer could ever fail to recognise the impact of the road funding policies of the present Federal Government in this area. This performance, and the comparatively deficient performance of our opponents, is pertinent to the debate.

The Hawke Government has a strong record in road funding, and has had since it came to office. It is a record which in comparison with the previous Government shows not only a broader long-term commitment to the overall road funding needs of the nation but an attempt to redress the past neglect of funding needs of certain States which suffered under the unequal distribution of funding in seven years of the Fraser-Howard Administration. Cold, hard facts support this view.

Federal road funding has increased substantially since the Hawke Government came to office. This Government has increased the level of actual road funding by 82 per cent since the last full year of the Fraser Government. The greatest individual increase has been in the funding of arterial roads. Despite being primarily a State responsibility, funding has increased by 31 per cent in real terms since this Government came to office. The allocation of funds for arterial roads for 1986-87 and the actual cash increase in Federal funding has been enormous. It has been 91 per cent or $201.6m. That is since the allocation of $422.3m since 1981-82.

Funding of local roads has increased by 10 per cent in real terms since the last full year of the previous Government. In 1986-87, the Government will continue to assist the rural sector with 75 per cent of all road funding going into national, rural arterial and rural local roads, creating employment and sustaining economic activity in rural Australia. If we compare these achievements in just three years of Labor Government with the seven year performance of the previous Liberal-National Party Government, the difference is nothing short of spectacular.

Let us consider these figures. In the last full year of the Fraser Government, 1981-82, Federal road funding was 25 per cent below that provided in the last full year of the previous Labor Government, 1974-75, and 30 per cent lower than the peak achieved in 1972-73. These figures are significant because they show the comparatively disastrous performance of our opponents in the area of road funding. This Government has maintained a considerable performance over a three-year period and any rationalisation of road funding in this legislation should be viewed within this context, particularly given prevailing economic circumstances.

This Government recognises that unless fundamental economic issues are addressed, the longer term implications for all Australians will be far more serious than the impact of a small adjustment to road funding. But this temporary adjustment should not mask the reality of a sustained and real improvement to road funding in this country, which must be appreciated in the context of the overall three-year performance of this Government, and not just within the constraints of this exceptional Budget year.

This effectively invalidates any criticism made by the Opposition in this debate about the level of road funding, the excise rate, the national highway, the ALTP, the ABRD or any other aspects of this legislation. This decision to adjust the ALTP excise rate and cash payment limit does not alter this Government's commitment to developing a better and safer road system for Australia. The variation in this excise is a one-off measure that is necessary in the present economic circumstances. The essential elements of the ALTP legislation, hypothecation and indexation will not be compromised and more than $810m will go into the ALTP trust fund to be used for future road funding.

For the first time in Australian history, a Federal government has set up a special trust fund to cover main road programs. This Government and the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) believe in planning for the future of Australia. While the ALTP excise rate has been marginally reduced, it will continue to be indexed in line with movements in the consumer price index, and the real value of road funding to the States will therefore be maintained. The fuel excise for the ABRD program remains unchanged. This Government has been able formerly to allocate a portion of excise for road funding despite difficult economic circumstances. Federal funding of local roads has increased by 2 per cent in this year's Budget and local government will benefit from not only the specific road funding but from general purpose assistance, which will be maintained in real terms over the next two years.

The national highway and bicentennial road programs have been enormous successes in the improvement of our roads. Australia now has a fully sealed highway, which stretches around the entire continent. This is something about which we should be proud. We have only to take to our highway to realise the benefits of this Government's road program. A map put out by the Minister for Transport and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) indicates the national highway very clearly, including improvement of roads, of course, in Tasmania. As I have said, it is something for us to be proud of as a government. Spending on the national highway will increase by $5m in 1986-87, and while some of the considerable objectives of the program may not be achieved within the original time span, the present Government has greatly improved the highway in all States.

This issue of equal distribution of road funding between each State is quite significant in this debate. SPEECH.PARA: Prior to the election of the Hawke Government in 1983, and with the notable exception of the Whitlam Government, the history of road funding by the Commonwealth was a sorry record of deliberate neglect. Previously, some Commonwealth funds had been made available through the Department of Repatriation for making or repairing development roads.

The Main Roads Development Act 1923 represented the first occasion on which the Commonwealth used its powers under section 96 of the Constitution to `grant financial assistance to any State on such terms and conditions as the Parliament sees fit'. That is, it was the first form of specific purpose grant. A grant of $1m was provided to the States in 1923-24 for expenditure on the construction of main roads, main trunk roads between important towns where no railways were provided and arterial roads through country areas unable to finance the heavy costs of road construction. The basic argument used in support of Federal Government road funding-to speed up the construction of main roads-is still used in support of Federal Government road grants today.

North Queenslanders bitterly remember that it was not until 1962, some 13 years after the Menzies Government took power, that the Bruce Highway from Brisbane to Cairns was completely sealed. In 1974 the Whitlam Labor Government introduced the National Roads Act and the Road Grants Act and thereby assumed full funding responsibility for roads which had been identified as being of special national significance, such as the national highways. This ambitious program to rebuild the land transport system of Australia was dealt a savage blow by the Fraser Government. For example, real road grants by the Federal Government to the States were slashed by 29.5 per cent during the seven years of the Fraser Government. Queensland suffered a major cut in Federal funding for roads. Almost all State governments and councils in Australia were furious at Federal government cutbacks in road funding.

Honourable members will vividly remember that during the years of the Fraser Government, Australian roads were cracking and crumbling under the strain of declining Federal government real funding for our national road network. There is no doubt that the Fraser Government's culpable failure to allocate a fair share of road users' taxation to the upgrading of Australia's road system was a direct cause of the increased tragic toll on the roads. It was an act of brutal cynicism and displayed a callous disregard for human life. The national highway was falling into decay. The then chief executive of the National Roads and Motorists Association, Mr George James, was reported in the Australian of 19 March 1982, as saying that the Fraser Government bore a `great responsibility for the failure to reduce the road toll'. He continued:

If New South Wales wants to achieve a major reduction in the road toll it will have to receive much better treatment from the Federal Government. In New South Wales we have how reached crisis point. We are now seeing the wastage of assets which will take generations to repair.

He blamed the cutbacks on the then Federal Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). On 17 March 1982 a report by the Bureau of Transport Economics on road construction price indices was tabled in this Parliament. The report confirmed that Fraser Government road funds, expressed in real terms, had been sharply reduced. It showed that road construction costs rose by 15.9 per cent in 1979-80 and by 15.3 per cent in 1980-81. These rises compared with increases in Fraser Government road funds of 7.5 per cent in 1979-80 and 11 per cent 1980-81. This sharp reduction in Fraser Government-funded road works was made when road users were being clobbered with a heavy fuel tax, levy increases and record personal taxation. The Liberal member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) was a member of the Fraser Government that trebled the price of petrol, quadrupled the fuel-related tax take and slashed more than half a billion dollars from road expenditure.

In 1981 more than 3,500 Australians were killed and about 90,000 were maimed or injured on Australia's roads. The appalling death and injury toll on Australia's roads, which cost $4 billion in the last year of the Fraser Government in monetary terms alone, was fostered by the Fraser Government's low priority on roads. There was no fairness in the Fraser Government's policies. While motorists paid the burden of tax evasion by shrewd operators, the Liberal-National Party Government squandered millions of dollars on lavish living for itself-international safaris, purchases of Boeing 707 flying hotels for overseas junkets, personal chefs and butlers, and propaganda to prop up an incompetent and dying government.

When the Hawke Government came to office, it was faced with a massive Budget deficit. During the 1983 election campaign it was suggested by the Fraser Government that the prospective 1983 Budget deficit would be of the order of $6 billion. After the election it was revealed that the prospective deficit was $9.6 billion. Notwithstanding these considerations, the Hawke Government recognised that a high priority had to be given to investment in roads as a basis for aiding economic development and creating jobs and to redress the decline in the road system which had occurred due to the previous years of Fraser Government neglect.

On 13 November 1984 the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Hawke) pledged to the Australian people that his Government would continue the greatest road building and maintenance program in Australia's history, that within the next three years the national highway system would be brought to an all-weather, dust-free and flood-free standard, and that the Bruce Highway would be transformed to give the growing cities and towns of north Queensland the genuine highway standard link they need and deserve. (Quorum formed)

As I said, on 13 November 1984 the Prime Minister pledged that his Government, an authentic Australian government, would initiate the most comprehensive overhaul ever undertaken of Australia's national transport system. In 1985 the Hawke Government passed legislation establishing the Australian land transport program. For the first time, Australia had a truly national transport strategy. The Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Act 1985 established a trust fund into which would be paid, as from 1 July 1985, an amount equivalent to 3.66c per litre of net revenue collected from Customs and excise duties on motor spirit and diesel fuel. That rate was to be subject to an adjustment twice yearly in line with movements in the consumer price index. The rate has been increased, from 1 August 1986, to 3.755c per litre. This provision is consistent with Australian Labor Party policy of returning a fairer share of fuel related revenue to road works funding.

Revenue from this duty during the year 1986-87 is estimated at $810m. Funds payable from the Australian Land Transport Program Trust Fund will be allocated on a percentage basis to national roads, urban arterial roads, rural arterial roads, local roads, land transport research and road safety. The Australian land transport program replaced the Roads Grants Act scheme which expired on 30 June 1985. The Australian bicentennial road development program is continuing separately.

Federal Government funding under the Hawke Government's Australian land transport program and the Australian bicentennial road development program will provide a record $1,250m for road construction, maintenance and research in 1986-87. By way of contrast, during the last full year of the Fraser Government-that is, 1981-82-a miserable sum of $685m was allocated for all road construction and maintenance. In other words, the allocation of Federal funds under these Hawke Government programs is 82 per cent more in money terms and 25 per cent more in real terms than that provided by the Fraser Government in 1981-82. Total spending on the 16,000-kilometre national highway will increase by $569m in this financial year compared with $559m last financial year.

The urgent need for adequate roads and the ever-increasing pressure on Australia's road system, especially the national highways, demand that road funding be placed on a predictable and assured basis. Now, for the first time ever, road funding under the Hawke Government is on a predictable and assured basis. Hawke Government road legislation gives encouragement for State and local road authorities, the construction industry and equipment suppliers to plan over a longer term, thanks to the certainty of funding. In contrast, the policy of the Liberal and National parties is the abolition of specific local road funding for the States and local government authorities.

The Australian land transport program provides the most comprehensive approach ever in funding for roads. This program will sustain the record level of Federal funding for roads which has occurred since the Hawke Government came to office. The Hawke Government is determined to achieve its commitment to upgrade the national highway system by 1988. The accomplishment of this great national undertaking will earn for the Hawke Government the enduring gratitude of every Australian. It is the fulfilment of a pledge made to the Australian people in the 1984 election policy speech by the greatest Prime Minister in Australia's history, Bob Hawke.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the adjournment debate tonight I want to talk briefly about the concept of multiculturalism and the importance to Australia of the extent to which this Government has let down the migrant community by largely terminating the English as a second language program. Certainly, one of the most important programs designed to ensure that multiculturalism is not separatism is that in which migrants are encouraged and aided to be able to speak English and to communicate within our community. It is evidenced by the desire of migrants, when they settle in Australia, to learn English and, particularly, the aspirations that they have for their children and their families in the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: It was therefore with great alarm that I learnt in the Budget that the Government had decided to reduce by almost half the amount of funding available for the teaching of English as a second language-the ESL program. Budgets are always a difficult question. It has always seemed to me that it is a matter of priorities. If priorities had to be determined in the cutting back of government expenditure in the education area, there are much more fundamental areas, I think, in which changes could have been made than the area of these ESL programs. I would have seen it as being most important to maintain those programs.

The immigration program brings to Australia each year a sizable number of students who have minimal or no proficiency in English on their arrival. Their need for intensive instruction in the English language is immediate and obvious. Without access to English they are deprived of access to education and to an alien culture. Within the group there are those whose pressing needs extend beyond English language instruction because they are illiterate in their mother tongue. These tend to be young people with refugee status who have received no schooling in their homeland or whose schooling has been seriously interrupted.

The Commonwealth, which is involved in bringing migrants to Australia, in inviting them to settle here, has a special responsibility in this area. The maintenance of these programs is of the utmost importance. I do not think the States, which will have the responsibility of ensuring that these programs are maintained, will see that they have the same responsibility in this area. I suspect that these programs will be sacrificed when the States have to examine their own priorities. In particular, the smaller States may not have had the same experience in these areas. Some schools which offer these programs, such as those in my own electorate, have small classes. Sometimes only 30 or 40 children in a school require special assistance through the English as a second language tuition program. TALK.START.PARA: —For some years now the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has been criticised for its lack of practical and economic understanding of the industry operations under its supervision. In April 1984 it announced in its publication Abtee that there was to be a review of its information needs. This was a response to the well-known criticisms of the way the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal was carrying out its responsibilities. These weaknesses had been long standing and were acknowledged in the final reports of the old Australian Broadcasting Control Board. On 19 April 1984, the ABT publicly announced that it had commissioned Professor Neil Runcie to conduct a review. The Press release said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Tribunal considers itself extremely fortunate in securing Professor Runcie's services, especially considering his extensive knowledge and experience in economic and statistical matters and close personal interest in the electronic media.

Why, then, were Professor Runcie's recommendations hidden from public scrutiny? In view of the public announcement of the review, the public would have expected a public report of the outcome of the review. The report was apparently due by 30 June 1984, but there was not mention of it in the 1984 or 1985 annual reports of the ABT. With some difficulty I have obtained a copy of the summary volume. The ABT was not forthcoming when I sought this report and it was necessary for me, as a member of parliament, to use the Freedom of Information Act to prise it out of the ABT. In contrast with the public fanfare given to the commissioning of the review, the receipt of the report and its contents have been kept very quiet. No wonder-because to make the report public would expose the ABT's serious internal weaknesses. The preamble of the Runcie report points out that:
to undertake economic analysis in the Australian broadcasting system three elements the ABT requires:
(i) an organised database;
(ii) a body of economic studies of the broadcasting industries, and;
(iii) qualified persons to apply economic perceptions and tools to the many broadcasting problems requiring government decisions.

The ABT is lacking in all of these areas. Professor Runcie also said that the information requirements of the ABT are wider than economic data, as the electronic media affect every aspect of our educational, social entertainment and cultural activities. In a biting comment at the end of the report, Professor Runcie says:

Indeed, the ABT has been likened to `Dad's Army' fighting imaginary battles with out-of-date equipment and getting in the way of the main broadcasting battalions. There is substance to these criticisms and the ABT must guard against the entropic effect of its `closed system', created by its excessively legalistic nature.
He goes on to say:

Throughout this report I have advocated a multi-disciplinary research programme to open up, as it were, the `closed system', thereby helping the ABT to serve better its functions and the Australian community.

The Runcie report documents many of the weaknesses in the present system and lists over 120 recommendations. It criticises the Coffs Harbour inquiry which was confused, costly and lengthy, confirming the need for more systematic information gathering from established stations as well as applicants for licences.

The Broadcasting and Television Act places a clear responsibility on the ABT to act as an information collecting body for the community, not just itself. The Runcie report expresses doubt about the ABT's fulfilment of this role. It strongly criticises the chaotic state of reporting by public broadcasters due to the confusing and inadequately designed forms used by the ABT.

I ask the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) four questions: Has he read this report? Why has the ABT been so secretive about it? Has it implemented the recommendations of the report? If not, why not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak, as so many of us have so often in the past, on behalf of the people of Chile, who have suffered now for 13 years under the repressive regime of the military dictatorship of General Pinochet. It is now 13 years since that dictatorship overtook the democratic processes in Chile. The torture, the killings, the imprisonments and the disappearances in Chile over those years have been well documented by groups such as Amnesty International. On Sunday 7 September 1986, after the attempt on the life of General Pinochet, the military regime reimposed the state of siege. The result of that has been a very much increased imposition of the repressive mechanisms of that regime. This has worsened the effect felt by the people of Chile.

SPEECH.PARA: To make the Australian public and the Australian Government more aware of what is happening in Chile, 11 young Chilean refugees in Australia began a hunger strike on 10 September, in Sydney, Melbourne and Perth. Since 4 p.m. on 10 September they have been refusing food. Six of those young Chileans are still fasting. Representatives of the Chilean youth came to Canberra today to make us aware of why their colleagues are undertaking that fearful way of showing the Australian public just how bad the repressive regime in Chile is. I read to the House the following statement that those young people put out:

Without any doubt, the reintroduction of the state of siege is just another measure used by the Chilean regime to increase its repression against those who oppose the dictatorship, and a way of openly arresting leaders of political and social organisations. In less than 24 hours, after the reinstatement of the state of siege, hundreds of people were arrested,-
this is just in the last few weeks-

some of whose whereabouts are not known, there have been massive and selective house searches, specially in shanty towns, all forms of meeting are banned. There is total censorship of the press, personal mail is intercepted and interfered with and any person who is arrested risks . . . exile and disappearance.

Amongst those who have been killed is Jose Carrasco, a member of the National Body of the Journalists Union. He was found dead on Monday the 8th in a street in Santiago. He had been shot in the head 10 times. Amongst those who have disappeared are the President of the Popular Democratic Movement, a clergyman and member of the executive body of the Popular Democratic Movement, members of the Democratic Alliance and a number of leaders of the teachers union. Eight priests have been arrested in the last few weeks and most of those arrested were taken away in front of witnesses as were four students who were abducted by the CNI, the secret police, from a Dutch diplomatic car.

Recently, with members of Amnesty International, I visited the Chilean Ambassador in Canberra to protest against the regime in Chile. We did not have to suffer the sort of thing that goes on in Chile when we made diplomatic representations. The Chilean youth resident in Australia have asked several questions of the Australian Government and the Australian people. They have asked the Australian Government, through a public statement, to condemn and denounce the recent escalation of repression imposed since the reinstatement of the state of seige. They protest and question the presence of the Chilean representatives in Australia who recently have made statements to the effect that everything in their country is all right and that the situation is the fault of those who are arrested. Is it the fault of the eight priests who were arrested recently? They call on the Government to interrupt the subsidies given to the private sector if it maintains economic ties with Chile. They call on the World Council of Churches to make a public statement regarding the latest wave of repression and violation of human rights inflicted upon the Chilean people and the Chilean church. They call upon the citizens of Australia to denounce the repression and come out in solidarity with the Chilean cause through their respective organisations, and I join them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to raise tonight concerns the harnessing of Australia's water resources. It has concerned me for a number of years. There has not been sufficient finance to further water conservation. At the present, I do not think we should accept the fact that our markets for primary industry are not good throughout the world as a reason why we should not use more funds generally for these most important projects. I realise that although it is the responsibility of the States to undertake these projects, over the years it has been the responsibility of the Commonwealth to undertake such projects as the Snowy Mountains scheme, and the Burdekin Dam in Queensland. Nevertheless, it is our responsibility as the main collector of funds in Australia to see that we have more money available for the development of this great continent. No matter what state our markets are in, no matter what state the economy is in, we will still be dependent upon the products from the farm to earn the wealth for this great nation of ours. Therefore, it is so important that we should not be left behind in the development of water conservation in our streams and our dam sites throughout Australia. Not only are these resources used for irrigation on farms but they are used also in many cases for domestic purposes. There is also a challenge today for the farmer to grow alternative crops, most of which are smaller crops such as oilseeds, maize, lucerne or other crops for which there may be markets within Australia and overseas. To be able to produce these crops at a reasonable cost it is essential that farmers have water for irrigation.

SPEECH.PARA: If one goes to America, Europe, or most primary industry countries throughout the world one finds that those countries have harnessed all the resources that they possibly can. In the western water district of California, in Sierra Nevada, there are about 250 dams which have been filled by melting snow. We do not have that quantity of snow here; we are not as lucky as America or other countries. We have done what we can with the snow we have in developing the Snowy Mountains scheme. But we have other natural areas which we can harness. We have rivers running into the sea and we can divert water from one area to another. These things can be done economically.

All the States have done a magnificent job in many respects. The State Ministers for water conservation have been restricted because they have not had the funds available. There is a tendency today-particularly for the Commonwealth and for most of the States-to disregard our great challenge to develop water resources. It is a challenge that we, as responsible people, cannot afford to let go. If we are to sustain our primary industries-42 per cent of our exports depend on what is termed `off the farm'-and if we are to meet the challenge of the economy of this nation over the years to come, we must meet that responsibility and divert more of these important funds into the great natural resources that we have in Australia. Not only are dams such as the Keepit Dam used for irrigation and domestic supply but they are used also for tourism.

TALK.START.PARA: —Correct.

—I am sure there are such dams in Tasmania. Most of these dams are a tremendous attraction for skiing, boating, and most forms of sport. In this way they are very important to Australia. I am very pleased to raise this matter before the House. We have to keep in mind that, no matter who sits on the treasury bench, the challenge is before them. Our minds should not be diverted by other unproductive projects which may take their place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am appalled at the outrageous hypocrisy of the Opposition members in this House. Time after time honourable members on that side of the House have uttered pious platitudes about the value of family life, yet when a Minister arranges that his family should not be left alone for many days at a time, the Opposition attacks him. Does the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have to neglect his family, have his young children grow up without a father, in order to do his job? Are Opposition members guilty because they choose politics before their children, or are they simply applying their usual double standard?

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon the Treasurer reminded the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) of a simple fact. If the Treasurer had sent his family back to Sydney, the Opposition would not have even raised this issue. If the Treasurer's wife and young children lived in Sydney while he worked his usual six to seven day week in Canberra it would not have attacked him at all. Who raised this issue? It was the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham), who moved his family to Brisbane so that he could be with them more often. He said, and I quote from the Sunday Territorian of 22 December 1985:

I am trying to fix up my personal life so that the people who depend on me are in the best personal situation . . . If I were a solicitor it would be different, but I am a Federal member who's away a lot.

If the honourable member for the Northern Territory believes that he can live in Brisbane and still represent his Northern Territory constituents, if my neighbours the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) can live well outside their electorates and still represent their constituents, I have no argument with that. If I have some concern about it I am prepared to accept that their families are best served by those somewhat unusual arrangements. What I do object to is a personal attack on a member of this Government for exercising the same concern for his family. Sauce for the honourable member for the Northern Territory is not apparently sauce for the Treasurer, and yet there is no doubt about whose contribution to the nation is the more important.

Australians have little time for the person who plays the man and not the ball. They have even less time for out and out hypocrites who say one thing and do another. Every time an Opposition member talks about the value of the family from now on, every Australian will be reminded that these are the people who wanted to separate the Treasurer from his family. These are the people who wanted the person carrying one of the nation's most important and demanding jobs to neglect his family. These are the people who wanted young children to grow up without their father. These are the people who put the family last in their priorities. What the Opposition hates is that a man can be a brilliant Treasurer and a good husband and father.

What does the Opposition want? Do members of the Opposition want everyone to conform to their doubtful standard because they are inadequate? Do they want to encourage the break up of families of members and Ministers? Do they have no respect at all for the values of family life? Do they care so little about the responsibilities of a growing family that they want those responsibilities carried by one parent? Are they totally without shame? Unfortunately the simple answer to all those questions is yes. No pretence is too great to stick in their throats. No double standard is too disgraceful for them to defend. No mud is too dirty to be thrown, and no ditch is too slimy to deter them.

One really has to have a strong stomach to sit in this House and listen to the Opposition, an Opposition whose members are incapable of producing policies that are not laughable, who substitute personal attack for their abysmal failure as policy makers, whose tactics match their characters, who plumb the depths of the political gutters and who want to rise like the phoenix from the ashes of their own incapacity.
